APPLICATION FOR ADMISSION

To the
Director of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada

Sir,

I hereby make application for admission of the undermentioned child into the Guy Residential School; to remain therein under the guardianship of the Principal for such term as the Minister of Mines and Resources may deem proper:

Indian name of child: Evelyn Okimaw
English name:
Age: 10 years born August 28, 1940
Name of Band: Peter Ballantyne
No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid: no. 279
Father's full name and No.: William Okimaw
Mother's full name and No.: Veronique McCallum
Parents living or dead: father is dead
State of child's health: good
Religion: R.C.
Does applicant speak English?: no
Previously attended: no school for years

Adopted by her grand mother: Catherine McCallum
(Signature of father)

Catherine McCallum

I hereby certify that the above application for admission has been read over and interpreted to the parent or guardian and that the contents were understood by him or her and that I witnessed his or her signature to this document.

*Signature of Missionary or other Witness*

*Principal or other official of the school must not sign as witness.*

NOTE—If mother or guardian signs, agent must forward full explanatory note.

I recommend the admission of the above child, who is of good moral character and is eligible to be admitted as a grant-earning pupil.

CANADA
The Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship & Immigration, OTTAWA, Ontario.

I am enclosing herewith for your approval Applications For Admission to the Guy Indian Residential School, Sturgeon Landing, Sask., on behalf of the under mentioned children.

Isaac Cook - No. 546 - Lac La Ronge Band
Noah Cook - " 546 - "
Solomon Cook - " 546 - "
Eva Cook - No. 299 - Peter Ballantyne Band
Martial Job - " 393 -

c.c. A. Giard.
July 27, 1950.

Mr. E.S. Jones,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Prince Albert, Sask.,

Your file 1034-107/25-2-655

With reference to your letter of the 20th instant, the Department approves the admission of the following children to the Guy Indian Residential School:

Isaac Cook
Noah Cook
Solomon Cook
Eva Cook
Martial Job
Charlotte McCallum
Jane McCallum
Alex Morin
Evelyn Okimaw

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.
Bishop's House,
The Pas, Man.
July 28th, 1950.

Mr. E.S. Jones,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Box 787,
Prince Albert, Sask.

Dear Sir:

When Mr. Bell, the sub-agent at Denare Beach, passed through here this summer on his return from Prince Albert, he carried a strict warning from your part that we should not hire Shieff (Aviation) Ltd., of Channing, Man. to carry the children from Brochet or South End as we had been doing in previous years.

The reason of this, if I understand well, is that Shieff Ltd. does not carry passenger-insurance and, did any accident occur, all responsibility and financial consequences which might be heavy would fall back on our own shoulders.

In consequence of this decision, we have hired Central Northern Airways, with the result that we are charged $354.00 a trip to Brochet instead of the $165.00 we were charged by Shieff.

In view of this heavy burden, which the Guy School is carrying alone, since we have received no special grant from Ottawa this last year for the plane transportation of 1949, I respectfully ask you if you would not agree of our going back to the old system of hiring Shieff Ltd. If you think it preferable, we could ask every Indian sending his child via Shieff Ltd. to stand responsible himself for any consequences. The Indians from Brochet or South End often fly with Shieff and think nothing of it. Furthermore I am told by the Father from Brochet last week that Shieff now has insurance for four adult passengers, which ought to stand for eight children.

We shall be glad to have your views on this matter soon, since we are already looking for planes, school opening at Sturgeon Landing on August the 15th.

With kind personal regards,

Yours truly,

(sgd) Rev. L. Poirier,
O.M.I.
Box 787,
Prince Albert, Sask.,
August 2nd, 1950.

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Post Office Building, REGINA, Saskatchewan.

I am enclosing herewith a copy of a letter from the Rev. L.
Poirier of the Bishop's House, The Pas, Manitoba, which will be
found self-explanatory.

I am at a loss to understand why the Department has not reimbursed
the Guy School at least in part in connection with their transportation
problems. You are aware that both the Lac la Ronge and St. Alban's
School have received a special grant for this purpose. I am of the
opinion the proper procedure in this case is through the channels of
your office.

E.S. Jones,
Superintendent,
Carlton Indian Agency,
Department of Citizenship & Immigration.

ESJ/jw
Regina, June 14th, 1950.

TO ALL INDIAN SUPERINTENDENTS

It has been brought to the attention of the Department that in one or more cases an unlicensed pilot has been hired to convey Indian children to and from Residential Schools.

This must not be done. You will instruct the Principals of Residential Schools that in future no Indian children travelling to or from the schools, at the expense of the schools or the Department, will be allowed to fly in an unlicensed aircraft or with an unlicensed pilot.

J.P.B Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship & Immigration,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

With reference to Department letter of the 9th of June, 1950, File 763-10(E1), regarding air transportation of Indian children to and from the Beauval Indian Residential School, I have to say that on May 29th, 1950, Dr. W.J. Wood, Regional Superintendent, Indian Health Services, Winnipeg, wrote me to the effect that Indian children from the Guy School were not to be returned to their homes by unlicensed plane operated by Mr. Shieff, of Brochet. On the date that the letter referred to was received instructions were issued to Indian Superintendent Jones, by telephone, that such air transport was not to be used for Indian children, and to so advise the Principal of the Guy School. Subsequently, on June 14th, 1950, a circular letter was sent to all the Indian Superintendents of this province with regard to air transportation of school pupils, and I am enclosing a copy of the same herewith.

I have now received a letter from Indian Superintendent E.S. Jones, of the Carlton Agency, with which he encloses copy of a letter he has received from Reverend L. Poirier, protesting against the high cost of air transportation when using a licensed plane.

It will also be noted that Indian Superintendent Jones is questioning the reason why the Department has not reimbursed the Guy School, at least in part, in connection with their transportation problems in view of the fact that similar assistance has been given at the Lac la Ronge School and St. Alban's School, in the Carlton Agency.

May the matter be carefully considered and instructions issued with regard to the matter under consideration.

Enclosed is a copy of Mr. Jones' letter above referred to, and Father Poirier's letter addressed to him.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies

The Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship and Immigration, Ottawa, Ontario.

I am in receipt of a letter from Father Giard, O.M.I., Principal of the Guy Indian Residential School, situated at Sturgeon Landing, Saskatchewan. The father states that Nancy Head, age 16 years, No. 234, Cumberland House Band, at my suggestion, has returned to the Guy Indian Residential School, and that she is taking Grade IX at the Provincial Government Day School recently opened at that point. Nancy has proved a good student in the past. May I request the same privilege be afforded this pupil and the Guy School as extended to pupils residing at the Lac La Ronge Indian Residential School attending the Collegiate in Prince Albert, namely the sum of $7.50 be paid each month to the Guy School for the pupil's board together with the cost of text-books, etc.

E. S. Jones,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.
October 20th, 1950.

Mr. E.S. Jones,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
P.O. Box 68,
Prince Albert, Sask.

Re: Guy Indian Residential School
Your File 1498-107/25-2-655

With reference to your letter of the 11th instant, it is noted that Nancy Head, a pupil of the Guy Residential School, is attending Grade 9 at the Provincial Government School.

The Department will continue to allow the per capita grant for her at the Guy School, and in addition an amount of $7.50 a month for the extra expense in attending the Provincial School, including the cost of textbooks, will be allowed.

A special Voucher at the rate of $7.50 a month should be forwarded either monthly or quarterly for this special payment. Her name should be continued on the Quarterly Return of the Guy School and per capita allowance will be paid for her.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education
The Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship & Immigration, Ottawa, Ontario.

I am in receipt of a letter from Father Giard, Principal of the Guy Indian Residential School which reads in part, "I want to recall a point about the transportation of the children. The last cheque of $2,000.00 is a payment for summer 1949; so far nothing has been paid already for summer 1950. As I am was telling me, this last summer 1950 we paid $4,349.23 for transportation of the children and I hope the Department will pay this amount."

In view of the fact that the children of this school all come from isolated sources thereby making the cost of transportation very high, it is presumed the Father is requesting a larger grant for this next year.

E. S. Jones,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.
November 21, 1950.

Mr. E.S. Jones,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Prince Albert, Sask.,

Further to our letter dated October 13th, 1950, file No. 1514-107/23-5-655, I am enclosing herewith a quarterly return for four children submitted by Rev. Father Giard, Principal of the Guy Indian Residential School, as at October 31st, 1950.

Also please find enclosed Admission & discharge of Pupils for July - September.

E. S. Jones,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.
Mr. Philip Thomas,
Chief, Education Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship and Immigration,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Recently, we have received the June-September Earnings for our Guy Indian Residential School in the amount of $11,742.00

May I respectfully submit that this amount of $11,742. represents the average attendance for our school of 164.8 pupils while our "Quarterly Return" for the same period showed an average of 168.68 pupils.

As we do not know where would be our error, we would appreciate if you could advise us about the difference of the two averages.

With sincere thanks in advance,

I remain,

Yours very truly,

Rev. Antonio Giard, O.M.I.
Principal
December 12, 1950.

Rev. A. Giard, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Guy Indian Res. School,
Sturgeon Landing, Sask.,

Dear Father Giard:

I have your letter dated December 7th in connection with a discrepancy on the September Quarterly Return for the Guy Indian Residential School.

I fail to see where you secure your average figure of 168.68 pupils, as your copy of the Return shows 162.37 and our figures are 164.80, an increase of 2.43 pupils. This increase was arrived at by increasing your grant to certain pupils who were truant during the Quarter but were in residence during the June Quarter. You claimed 46 days. We paid at 62 days. The pupils involved were pupils 229, 231, 235, 260, 263, 266, 301, 320, 325, 0209, 0227, 0274, 0297 and 0305.

I hope this information will suffice.

Attached is a supplementary Return received, on which no action can be taken at this time as the September Return has been paid. It is suggested that the pupils shown on it be included on the December Return with a note showing the grant for them was not claimed on the September Return.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6314, file 655-10, part 3)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship & Immigration, Ottawa.

Reference letter 655-10 (E6) dated November 21, 1950. Attached hereto you will find a statement of expenditures in connection with Air Transportation for pupils attending the Guy Indian Residential School, received from the Principal of the school concerned amounting to $4,349.23.

I recommend the School Administration be reimbursed.

E. S. Jones,
Superintendent,
Carlton Indian Agency.

Encs.
Dear Sir:

You will notice that some children have a total number of days greater than the others.

The No. 339 was here last year; he is attending the school since August 1949 but unfortunately I received his admission only on October 1950; so it is the first time that his name is included on the Quarterly Return.

The Nos. 240, 241 and 0354 were accepted only on October 1950, so their names figure on the Quarterly Return for the first time.

I hope that the Department will pay for these four pupils who have admitted only recently.

I thank you very much and I remain,

Yours very truly,

A. Giard
O.M.I.
Principal.

Sir,—
I hereby make application for admission of the undermentioned child into the (Sturgeon Landing) Residential School; to remain therein under the guardianship of the Principal for such term as the Minister of Mines and Resources may deem proper:

Indian name of child: Gilbert Linklater
English name:
Age: born Aug 16th 1940
Name of Band: Peter Ballandine
No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid: #253
Father's full name and No.: Peter Linklater #203
Mother's full name and No.: Catherine Linklater #253
Parents living or dead: living
State of child's health: Fair
Religion: Roman Catholic
Does applicant speak English? Yes
Previously attended: day (Residential Boarding School for years)

(Signature of father)

I hereby certify that the above application for admission has been read over and interpreted to the parent or guardian and that the contents were understood by him or her and that I witnessed his or her signature to this document.

Signature of Missionary or other Witness

*Principal or other official of the school must not sign as witness.

NOTE—If mother or guardian signs, agent must forward full explanatory note.

I recommend the admission of the above child, who is of good moral character and is eligible to be admitted as a grant-earning pupil.

Agent

NOTE—All the above particulars must be fully given, especially the "Name of Band," "No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid" and "Religion." When application is made for the admission of such cases, full particulars should accompany the application.

The Pas, Manitoba.
October 17, 1951.

Mr. R.S. Davis,
Regional Supervisors of Indian Agencies,
537 Dominion Public Bldg.,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Dear Mr. Davis:

Please find applications for admission to Sturgeon Landing Residential School, unsigned as per your instructions. They were received in this office October 12, 1951.

It has been the practice of these Northern Residential Schools to wait till the pupils are brought into the school from isolated reserves and then have the doctor examine, making application for their admission when they have already entered school. I would like to point out that pupils entering Prince Albert Residential School have been handled very much the same way. Just before the child gets on the train for the school, applications are received for admission. I brought this matter to the attention of the escort representing this school, who was in The Pas to take the children to Prince Albert. I told him I would forward the applications to Ottawa, but if they were not accepted they would have to pay the child's return fare.

Please advise what action will be taken on this matter.

Yours truly,

E. Law,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I am enclosing herewith Application forms for the following children, who are now in the Sturgeon Landing Residential School:

Esther Adam, No. 70 Lac La Hache Band
Therese Marie Veuillot, No. 119 Barren Lands Band
Edna Moose, No. 216 Nelson House Band
Marie Aline Colomb, Mathias Colomb Band
Pelagie Hart, Mathias Colomb Band
Louise Sinclair, Mathias Colomb Band
Adelaide Michell, No. 82 Barrrens Lands Band
Marie Julienne Bighetty, Mathias Colomb Band
Cecilia Denechezhe, No. 109 Barren Lands Band
Sarazine St-Pierre, No. 95 Barren Lands Band
Marie Annie Tssessaze, No. 108 Barren Lands Band
Ovide Denechezhe, No. 109 Barren Lands Band
Martin Veuillot, No. 119 Barren Lands Band
Marcel Tssessaze, No. 108 Barren Lands Band
Pierre Joseph Tssessaze, No. 118 Barren Lands Band
Jean Tssessaze, No. 118 Barren Lands Band
Abraham Samuel, No. 124 Barren Lands Band
Isaac Michell, No. 82 Barren Lands Band
Jean Baptiste Benaoni, No. 105 Lac la Hache Band
Jean Gazandlare, No. Stony Rapid Band
Rodolphe Gazayoue, No. 41 Lac La Hache Band.

Mr. Law took this matter up with me, as these children were just picked up and put in the school and the applications submitted sometime after. I advised him to forward the applications and he need not sign them, as these children were already in school without his permission,

(over)
or without consulting him.

I would recommend that in this case these applications be accepted. However, schools should be notified that in future they are not to recruit or take children in without first consulting the Superintendent concerned, and having the applications approved by the Department. The sooner this matter is brought in line the better.

R. S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Encls.
RSD/ES

October 27, 1951

Rev. A. Giard, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Guy Indian Res. School,
Sturgeon Landing, Sask.,

Dear Father Giard:

We have received from Mr. R.S. Davis, Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies a number of applications for the admission of pupils to the Guy Indian Residential School.

Mr. Davis has forwarded a covering letter which reads in part as follows:

"I would recommend that in this case these applications be accepted. However, schools should be notified that in future they are not to recruit or take children in without first consulting the Superintendent concerned and having the applications approved by the Department. The sooner this matter is brought in line the better".

In order to maintain friendly relations with the Indian Superintendent you should consult him when preparing the list of pupils who are admitted to the school for the first time.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

November 12, 1951

Mr. E.S. Jones,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Prince Albert, Sask.,

With reference to the September Quarterly Return for the Guy Indian Residential School, it would be appreciated if you would bring the following remarks to Father A. Giard's attention:

1. It is noted that on the Return is claimed forty-seven days for pupils who did not return to school during the month of September. The practice has been to allow sixty-two days covering grant for July and August for these pupils. We have consequently increased the grant to sixty-two days in all cases.

2. Father Giard has claimed sixty-one days for pupils 269, 0281 and 0330 indicating in the "Remarks" column that the pupils were sent to sanatorium and indicating that each had attended classes during the month of September. As these pupils were shown to have attended school during the June Quarter and were in residence during the month of September full grant of ninety-two days is allowed. The figure ninety-two days is arrived at as follows:

(a) The school is entitled to sixty-two days for July and August

(b) As the pupil was in residence during the month of September, the school is entitled to thirty days hospitalization grant
3. Pupils 320, 0289, 0323 and 0341 were not in residence during the June Quarter consequently no grant can be allowed for them for the months of July and August. However, the school is entitled to thirty days grant for the month of September. We have adjusted the September Return accordingly.

This information should be given to the Principal in order that she can bear it in mind when preparing future Returns.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
Extract from letter of Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander,
dated December 28, 1951.

Re: Guy Residential School

I would also refer to Father Giard's remarks
that the allowance of $2,000.00 which the Department makes
to him toward the transportation of the school children
by plane is about $3,000.00 short of the actual cost to the school.
Is it possible to increase this allowance?
January 28, 1952.

Mr. J.F.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
304 Post Office Building,
Regina, Saskatchewan.

Re: Guy Indian Residential School

I wish to refer to that portion of your letter of the 28th ultimo in which you mention the allowance for transportation of pupils.

The funds at our disposal will not permit us to increase the sum which we allow. As a matter of fact, it is fair to presume that the expenses would not be so heavy if the management did not recruit so many children, and as stated in a previous part of your letter, their action in this regard is overcrowding the school.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship & Immigration,

Enclosed herewith you will find Quarterly Return for
the Guy Indian Residential School for the quarter ending
December 31, 1951. Father Giard Principal of the School made
the following comments when submitting this return:

1. "You will notice many children are gone to the San and I
wonder if I should have marked more days of residence in the school
according to a letter of Mr. Phelan: "As the pupil was in
residence during the month of September, the school is entitled
to thirty days hospitalization grant" v.g. some left on December
6, then I add only 6 days but according to these words I should
take 31 days; is it the right way to interpret his words?

2. "At your last visit, I have showed to you a letter of Mr.
Phelan in which he blamed me because the children were before
their formal admissions were given by Ottawa; as you know better
than me, it is impossible for the North; last Fall I send
applications for admissions and now I am sending you some more
applications and I hope that all these children will be admitted."

E. S. Jones,
Superintendent,
Carlton Indian Agency.
February 18, 1952.

Mr. E.S. Jones,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Box 68, Prince Albert, Sask.,

Your file 212-107/23-5-655

With reference to your letter of February 8th regarding the December Quarter Return for the Guy Indian Residential School, we wish to bring to your attention the fact that the school is entitled to 30 days grant following the date the pupil was admitted to a hospital.

In your letter you pointed out that a pupil left residence on December 6th. In such cases the school is entitled to a grant of 67 days plus 30 days hospital grant or a total of 92 days on the December Quarter plus 5 days on the March Quarter.

Please bring this matter to the Principal's attention for his information when completing future Returns.

With reference to the application for admission to the Guy Indian Residential School, the Department approves the admission of all the children listed in your letter except the following:

Albert Linklater
Achille Linklater
The parents of these children are living and the children have attended the Nelson House Day School for two and three years respectively. Please advise why you consider it necessary that these children receive institutional care.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship & Immigration, Ottawa.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter 655-10(E6) dated February 18, 1952.

Referring to the last paragraph concerning Albert Linklater and Achille Linklater, as these children are members of The Pas Agency, I am unable to answer your query.

E. S. Jones,
Superintendent,
Carlton Indian Agency.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I am forwarding herewith applications for the admission of the following children to the Guy Indian Residential School, which is located on the Saskatchewan and Manitoba Border.

Clemintine Linklater
Helen Bighetty
Emma Moys

Mathias Colomb
Mathias Colomb
Brochet

I am advised by Superintendent Law that these children were all discharged from the Clearwater Sanatorium and sent to the Guy Residential School by Dr. Yule. He did not send them home for the winter as they would not receive proper care on the reserve. However, I feel that Dr. Yule should have taken this matter up with Superintendent Law before making this move, and it could have been done in time for the applications to have been approved before the children were admitted to school.

R. E. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

June 26, 1952.

Mr. E.S. Jones,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Prince Albert, Sask.,

With reference to your letter of June 2nd regarding the Department's contribution for transportation charges for children admitted to the Guy Indian Residential School in 1951, your attention is directed to your letter of January 8, 1951 in which you enclosed receipted accounts submitted by the Principal of the Guy Indian Residential School. On receipt of these accounts the Department forwarded a cheque for $2,000. to the Guy Indian Residential School to re-imburse part of the expenditure made by Father Giard.

It would be appreciated, therefore, if you would ask Reverend Giard, Principal of the Guy Indian Residential School to forward you the receipted accounts for transportation charges paid last year and we will arrange to forward a cheque equal to the amount forwarded for the previous year.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Sir:

Please find enclosed copies of requests made by Rt Rev. Bishop Charlebois for the Guy Boarding School at Sturgeon Landing.

As His Lordship intends to send the newly appointed Principal of the above school at Sturgeon Landing in July to start work on the land he would feel grateful to the Department for sending the instruments, tools, horses etc in the beginning of the same month. I have already mentioned to you the request of His Lordship for having land near the site of the school, said land being part of the intended Reserve. I wish to add that a list of blacksmith's and carpenter's tools will be sent to the Department at our earliest convenience.

Hoping that you will give the above matter your usual kind attention, I remain,

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR HAMILTON,
DATED OCTOBER 24th, 1928, ON HIS INSPECTION
OF THE GUY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

---

Original on #132-7-5.

Five cows are kept at the school, but they were in poor condition and, in fact, appeared to be a poor dairy type. Hay is hard to get as the country is all bush and swamp. The Principal claimed he had 60 loads, but in order to get it he was obliged to go a distance of nearly 20 miles. It is impossible for the cows to provide milk sufficient for 105 children, as well as a staff of 12 or 14. If more cows cannot be kept, the milk supply could be supplemented by powdered milk. I believe milk added to the children's diet would be of great benefit.

---
I would particularly draw your attention to what the Inspector says regarding the type of cows that are kept at this school, and also the small number that are kept. This, to my mind, is a very important matter. Indians are subject to tuberculosis and unless they get proper and nourishing food, milk in particular, they will fail. As a matter of fact, under the best conditions, they cannot stand confinement as well as white children, so the Department should insist on the proper number of cows being kept at this school. Of course, if there is no way of producing feed for these cows it is another matter, but I have no doubt there is a means of supplying the necessary feed or the Department would never have built a school at this point. These children will be undernourished unless they get milk, especially where fish forms a large part of the diet.
Dear Dr Moore:

Have today returned from Guy School, at Sturgeon Landing. I accompanied Dr Ridge and his technician. All pupils and Staff were X Rayed in record time, as we did not arrive there until after four yesterday afternoon, and were back to The Pas at 10.30 this morning, no time was wasted.

As this school can be definitely classified as in the over crowded class, the question of the health of the children has been giving me some concern. However, these fears appear to be groundless, as there has been less sickness this season, than any year since my association with the school. I, however, discovered nine new cases of enlarged neck glands, since my last visit. It would seem, as if the bovine population of the school should be checked for TB. They have seven cows milking at present, and these with the young cattle make up a herd of twenty. To date, I have found comparatively few enlarged glands amongst these children. I think, that these cattle should be tuberculin tested in the not too distant future. The necessity for it, and having it done is a different matter. I could do it myself, but my plans do not call for a visit there again until next September. It requires at least a twenty-four forty-eight hour stay. I do not think, that another school year should begin, without this matter being cleared up. This would be the case, if nothing is done before next fall.

I discussed the question with Father Poirier, who is willing and anxious to co-operate. The matter will again be mentioned in my February report, but as that will not reach you for another month, I decided to report at once. Would hate to see it drag along, like Red Earth, as nothing has yet been done there, although the question was raised in 1942.

Yours trul$,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter 122-7-10, dated the 19th instant, and forms you enclosed regarding making an enquiry into deaths that occur at Guy Indian Residential School.

I cannot see how your instructions contained on the form can be complied with. Guy Residential School is sixty miles from here and it is difficult to get there either winter or summer, nor are there any regular means of communication. There is no one residing at Sturgeon Landing outside the school staff to whom I could delegate authority to act for me. In addition there is no doctor. Dr. La Rose from The Pas visits the school every three months. I could of course make a special trip accompanied by the doctor when a death occurs, though it would be practically impossible to get there for several days, probably a week after the death occurred. The Principal would have to send in word into The Pas and then I would have to get word back to him to meet us at Atik. It almost every case it would be impossible to notify the pupil's parents of the death as they live, for the most, in very remote districts, a great distance from the school.

A special trip by myself and the doctor would cause considerable expense. Deaths at the school are not very numerous, though there has been this last two months. After you have considered the above report, I would like your further instructions in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Pttawa

Dear Sir,-

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 25th instant, with reference to completing the forms in connection with the death of a pupil at the Guy Indian Residential School.

From the information contained in your letter, it is evident that all the procedure mentioned on the form cannot be carried out. At the same time, it is necessary that we should have on file as complete information as possible regarding the circumstances attending the death of any pupil in a residential school.

The forms that were sent to you should be forwarded to the Principal and, in the event of the death of a pupil, the Reverend Sister who acts as nurse and the Principal should supply on the form as much information as they can and, when this is done, the form should be sent to you and you should forward it to the Department.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of 
Elizabeth Rat, Pupil No. 144, 
of the 
Tay Indian Residential School at 
Sturgeon Landing, 
who died at 
Tay School (place) on October 19th, 1952.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the 
Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, 
consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical 
Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's 
presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of 
Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's 
death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be 
permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked 
if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be 
attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after 
the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it imprac-
ticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. 
A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal 
Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind 
might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for 
this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach 
the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including 
an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the state-
ments of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Form No. 414.
A. STATEMENT OF THE PRINCIPAL OF THE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

1. On what date did this pupil fall sick or suffer injury? October 11th, 1938.

2. At what time of day? During the night.

3. When and to whom did he or she report this illness or accident? To the nurse who attended until the end.

4. What means were taken to afford relief? The sick girl was kept in bed.

5. What medicines were used for this purpose and in what dose or quantity? Phine.

6. When was the doctor called? No communications possible to give notice to the doctor by the parents.

7. If the pupil was removed to hospital, at what time was this done and by what means of transport?

8. If the pupil was not removed to hospital, what measures were taken for his or her care at the school? Proper care was taken; the girl was not left alone for minutes.

9. Add any other useful information here.

Children are everything since two weeks, two or three cases of sleeping sickness. This is one that degenerated in pneumonia.

Parents are living 150 miles from the school. They have been notified, will receive the letters later.

R.W. N. Dyer, C.M.S.
Principal.

NOTE: If the deceased pupil dies in hospital at a distance from the school, under the care of the physician or surgeon who attends him at the hospital, a clinical report of the patient's illness and death in the hospital is to be secured and attached to this memorandum.

Guy Indian Residential Boarding School
Sturgeon Landing, Sask.
October 20th, 1939.

Mr Samuel Lovell, Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.

Dear Sir:

Sad news today.... One little girl died in the school. I wrote to the parents this last Wednesday and told them that their girl was very sick though the case was not yet desperate. I had in mind to send her to the hospital by plain Wednesday, but she was too weak already; and to call the doctor it was impossible. I regret this happened in the school, but we have to take it as it comes, after having done our best. I have filled the form required by the Dept., hoping the statement will be satisfactory.

Children are coughing yet. I do not know what will be the result of this epidemic; however not one child in bed. I would like to see the doctor here, but it is quite impossible at this time of the year. You must have received my letter last Wednesday.

If you can you will send to me copies of Form No 414 in case some other deaths occurred during the year.

Yours truly,

Rev. N. Doyon, R.C.S.P.
Principal.
Dear Sir,

I have been instructed by Mr. S. Lovell, Indian Agent to forward the attached report, in connection with the death of Elizabeth Rat at Guy Indian Residential School.

The enclosed letter from the Principal dated Oct. 20th has only just been received. No doctor attended the patient, as owing to transportation difficulties, it was impossible to get one.

Mr. Lovell has left for Red Earth Reserve. He does not think that a visit to the School by himself and the Doctor would fill any useful purpose and that everything in connection with the death has been explained by the Principal. It would be difficult, in fact almost impossible to get to Sturgeon Landing just at present.

Your obedient servant,

S. Lovell,
Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Form No. 414.
A. STATEMENT OF THE PRINCIPAL OF THE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

1. On what date did this pupil fall sick or suffer injury?...took to bed end of October 1942

2. At what time of day?

3. When and to whom did he or she report this illness or accident? Child did not report himself but the nurse at the school found out by herself.

Usual care of T.B. cases out of Sans: better food, rest, fresh air, etc...

4. What means were taken to afford relief?

5. What medicines were used for this purpose and in what dose or quantity? Cod liver oil and cough mixture.

6. When was the doctor called?...Doctor came on the 1st of December...

7. If the pupil was removed to hospital, at what time was this done and by what means of transport? First taken to the Jess Hospital by plane on the 3rd of December.

8. If the pupil was not removed to hospital, what measures were taken for his or her care at the school?

9. Add any other useful information here.

Principal.

THE DECEASED PUPIL

to April 24th, 1943. The immediate cause of death was
Chronic pulmonary Tuberculosis.

Murray Campbell M.D.

Prince Albert, February 10th 1897.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No 1754 of the 4th inst., referring to the question of a supply of biscuits for the school at Montreal Lake and Lac La Ronge for the next fiscal year, and in reply to say that I earnestly hope the biscuits will be supplied and the schools continued. I am not aware of any reason why they should be closed, and I think that even if it is thought desirable to close some of the day schools, those in isolated places, such as the above mentioned should be kept open if possible.

I am, etc.,
sgd J.A. Mackay.

The Indian Commissioner.
Regina.

Note:- Reference Department's letter No 116648 of November 9th 1896.

for Commissiner.

SCHOOL BRANCH

OTTAWA 23rd March 1897:------

THIS LETTER HAS BEEN SENT

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of a copy of a letter from Archdeacon Mackay, relative to biscuits for the Montral Lake and Lac la Ronge Schools; and in reply I beg to say that biscuits may be supplied these schools as heretofore.

Your obedient servant,

Deputy Supt:genl:
of Indian Affairs:

The Indian Commissioner,
Regina, N.W.T.
Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No. II0/21 of the 20th ultimo, enclosing two extracts from Inspector Chisholm's Report on the School at Little Hills or Lac la Ronge, and in reply to state the same will have careful consideration. It is however an extremely difficult matter to secure the services of a thoroughly qualified teacher for such a distant and isolated place and, as the Inspector was informed, the attendance of the pupils is very irregular on account of the unsettled mode of life of the people.

I am, Sir,
Yours obly.

J.A. MacKay

The Indian Commissioner,
Winnipeg.
Sir,

I have the honour to refer to paragraph No. 15 of Mr. Inspector Chisholm's report of his inspection of Lac la Ronge and Montreal Lake Bands, and my note in connection therewith respecting the Day School at the former place and to enclose a letter from Rev. Archdeacon McKay, Prince Albert, on this same subject, being an answer to a letter asking him to endeavor to secure improvement in the management of this School. From this letter it will be seen that there is little hope of the Church Authorities being able to secure the services of a more competent teacher than the one now in charge. This coupled with the small and irregular attendance prevailing at that School, the question arises whether it is worth while to keep such a school open.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Commissioner

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
A. E. Forget, Esq.,
Indian Commr.,
Winnipeg, Man.

Ottawa 16th Feb. 1897.

Sir,

I have to ask the rec't of your letter of the 17th ult. No. 110/21 enclosing a copy of a letter from the Rev. Mr. Macdonald in respect to the day school at Lac la Rouge.

Although it is very probable that it is almost impossible to obtain a properly competent teacher for this school, as the enrollment for the last quarter was 25 with an average attendance of 8.5, the Dept. thinks it would not be advisable to close this school.

Yours obediently,

J. D. McLean
Secretary
Clothing. I beg to ask for—

9 boys blankets
30 yds serge
6 pair boys trousers
15 yds Etoffe.

(aged) A. Keith

In this connection I would refer to Dept letter of 16th Feb last No. 11648 and my letter of 17th Janv last No. 11921 and would say that if the Dept still considers it advisable to keep this school open, it will be necessary that the expenditure indicated by Mr. Keith be increased, in which event authority should be given the said Capt. Carleton and the stationery be asked for be sent him.

(aged) A.E.F. Conr.

It is thought that as the building is used as a church, the church authorities should contribute the stove pipes. That on larger scale will doubtless be required for a school on the new "Southern" Rd. If there are any removals thereto from Montreal Lake.

(aged) A.E.F. Conr.
If the school is continued, it would be advisable to supply the small quantity of clothing asked for in order to ascertain whether the Indians are sincere in their promise to leave their children for the winter.

(Agd) A.E.F.
Commissioner
Extract (original on 156710)

Ottawa 5th Oct-98

W.J. Chisholm, Esq.
Inspector, D.A.

Sir,

Further on in his report Mr. Keith speaks of the Indian school at Little Hill which he considers a poor one and the teacher an ex-pupil of Emmanuel College not very competent, not being able to speak English intelligently. This man has taught for 5 years at the Little Hill school. He has 18 pupils all but 2 of whom are in the first standard. Mr. Keith says the building requires window frames and he gave instructions to have grass cut for thatching the roof.

(Signed) R. Pimm
For Secy.
Extract (Original on 156710)

Prince Albert - Last.
Sept 8th 1898

Sir,

The school at Little Hill is a poor one and the teacher, an Indian from Cumberland, a finish from Emmanuel College, not much good. He can't speak English intelligently. He has 18 children, all but 2 of which are in the first standard. He has been teaching there for 5 years. This does not say much for his success. Of course Indians come and go and it is difficult to show progress.

The school house, used as a church, is a log building 16 x 34. Four windows two of which require window frames, only having the holes cut and a piece of cotton.
cotton nailed up. The roof leaks. I told some of them to cut the thatch grass while it was good. Fifteen dollars would thatch the roof. A lock is required for the door. If this school is to be continued, the following articles will be required at once—

20 lbs rice
25 lbs soap
2 combs
1 wash-basin
10 yds towelling
1 set alphabet cards
1 set animal cards
6 slates
1 Box chalk
1 Box slate pencils.

The walls look bare, the animal and alphabet cards would anyway give it the appearance of a school. A new boy stove and piping is required. I suggested building a mud chimney but they say the mission people
people object to this as they use the building for a church.

Allow me to remind you that we have a box stove, stationery, basins and outfit at the Sturgeon Lake Reserve from the school once held there, which would be available.

My opinion is the school is no good and is only a bill of expense the way it has been conducted. I asked some of the Indians why they did not send their children more regularly, but they say they have to take them when off shooting hunting. I suggested that they should leave them with some of the old people who winter at Little Hills and leave a supply of fish and send to them now again. They agreed to this if I would get them some clothing.
REPORT on the INSPECTION of
WILLIAM CHARLES' and JAMES ROBERTS' BANDS.

Date of Inspection, Aug. 8th to 23rd, 1905.

The Lac la Ronge day school was not in session on either occasion as I passed. It is situated at Little Hills, some nine miles west of Lac la Ronge. It may, I presume, be taken for granted that it will be closed as soon as the new Boarding School is prepared to receive pupils.

Respectfully submitted

W. J. Chisholm,
Inspector of Indian Agencies

Mistawasis, Sept. 22nd, 1905.
Report on the Inspection of William Charles and James Roberts' Bands,
From August, 1905, to August, 1906.
Date of inspection, August 10th to 18th, 1906.

Day School.
I was not consulted about the scheme of erecting two buildings. The plan I saw was for one building.

D. L.,
Indian Commissioner.

14. The day school has been closed since May. So far as I was able to learn there was no authority for the closing. However, as shown in my former reports there was no advantage in keeping it open.

Respectfully submitted,

W. J. Chisholm,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

I authorized the day school to be closed when the Boarding School was opened.

D. L.,
Indian Commissioner.

Prince Albert, October 22nd, 1906.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Roll. This is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. Where, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES

CANADA
NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper column.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL QUARTERLY RETURN

I HEREBY CERTIFY that the within Return is a true and faithful statement of the attendance and tuition at the ALL SAINT'S INDIAN School for the Quarter ended DECEMBER 31 1949.

Principal

Dated Jan 7 1950

I have carefully examined the within Return and hereby certify that it is correctly made out in accordance with the instructions of the Department.

CARLTON

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.
