Ottawa, June 16, 1923.

Reverend Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 11th instant, enclosing accounts covering the payments made for freighting motor boat, pump, engine and other supplies from Prince Albert to the Lac la Ronge Indian Boarding School, also accounts from the Hudson's Bay Co. for the labour and material supplied on the building of a storehouse and stable.

In reply I beg to say we regret that it is necessary to return these accounts as they are not in order for payment. In connection with the accounts for freighting, it will be necessary for you to prepare vouchers, in duplicate, containing itemized statements of the various amounts paid. A pad of forms for this purpose is being sent you under separate cover. This supporting voucher should be made in your favour, certified by you and one copy of the receipts in each case attached thereto and returned to the Department. We require only one copy of these receipts and you may retain the duplicate.

Regarding the account covering the labour and material on the storehouse and stable, I would point out that there is no receipt for the item of windows for storehouse and stables. We are not aware as to whether a cheque in payment of the amount due should be sent to the Hudson's Bay Co. as their account has not been receipted. The certificate attached by the Principal for the labour is satisfactory, but a properly certified account covering the cost of the windows should be forwarded. If payment is to be made to you, it will be necessary to have the accounts receipted by the Hudson's Bay Co. If, however, a cheque is to be sent the Company, a properly certified account from the Principal should be forwarded covering the cost of the windows. As soon as we have these accounts in proper order, as required above, payment will be made.

I may say that, in future, when forwarding accounts for which payment is made to yourself, you should make out, in duplicate, an itemized voucher on the forms which are being sent you and it should be certified by you. The above instructions are in conformity with the requirements of the Auditor General before payments can be made.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. W. R. TAYLOR, PAYING AGENT FOR TREATY 10, ON HIS RECENT TRIP TO MAKE THE ANNUAL PAYMENTS TO THE INDIANS OF THE ISLE A LA CROSSE AGENCY.

JAMES ROBERTS BAND:
This band at Lao La Ronge was paid on the 14th of July. I found this band in good health, and showing an increase of 8 over last year. The people here are nearly all Anglicans. The Residential School here had closed down for the summer holidays, I therefore could not examine the work of the pupils. There is a nice garden in connection with the school, which will produce nearly all the vegetables required. I mentioned in my report last year, the need of safer chimneys in this school, and I would again draw attention to this matter, as I found that no material had been supplied. The winter is the best time to get brick into this place, as the Brooks Transportation Co. do freighting to this point during the winter months from Prince Albert.
Ottawa, September 25, 1923.

Reverend Sir,

It has been brought to the attention of the Department on several occasions, the unsafe condition of the chimneys at Lac la Ronge School. In order to remedy this defect, you are authorized to have built stone or brick chimneys. It is thought, however, that stone chimneys can be more economically built than brick chimneys, using cement mortar, but the Department will leave to your judgment to decide which to use, as this will be governed by local conditions.

If stone chimneys are built, you should employ a competent stone mason and pay his expenses in and from the school, and wages while working. You may also purchase the amount of cement that will be required for the mortar.

Vouchers in duplicate should be submitted to the Department for all expenditures, and when labor is employed, time sheets should be kept showing the number of hours worked and the rate per hour.

Your obedient servant,

(A. F. MACKENZIE)
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Reverend Chas. F. Hives,
Principal, Indian Boarding School,
Lac la Ronge - Sask.

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

In a letter just received from the Rev. C. F. Hives, Principal of our Society's School at Lac la Ronge, he informs me of four very important requirements for that institution. They are as follows:

1. Additional battery cells for the Delco Light system.
   The following is an extract from his letter in this connection:
   "It is very necessary that we should have these during this coming winter. Our plant was supplied with 16 cells. It has been found that that number is insufficient, and the Delco Light Co. do not install any plants the size of ours with less than 32 cells. We need, therefore 16 additional cells, the cost of which will be about $250.00 delivered here."

2. Pipe connections for the pump.
   Last year your Department kindly furnished this school with a new pump, but when it arrived it was found that larger piping was required than what was on hand. As it was greatly desired that this piping should reach the school before the freighting season closed, I authorized the principal to secure it, but through the inability of our freight contractor to get it through to the school before the roads broke up, the school has been obliged to get along as best it could without it all through the summer. It is estimated that this will cost, delivered at the school, about $130.00, and as I have again given instructions for this to be taken through with the first loads of freight, I presume that it will be quite in order for me to submit the bill to you for payment as soon as it comes to hand. In this connection I should like to refer you to my letter of April 14, 1923, where the quantity and measurements of the pipe required are set forth.
The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs.

3. Fire Hose Equipment.
In this connection Mr. Hives writes as follows:- "We should also have fire hose equipment for our building. We have nothing in that respect at present, but I am more and more convinced that we should have this means of protection".

4. An Evinrude Engine.
The needfulness of this is set forth by Mr. Hives in the following words:- "It requires a great deal of fish to keep us going, and either we will have to get an assistant fisherman or else get an Evinrude engine to attach to a boat for fishing. The latter I think would be the better as we will have to go farther away from the school in order to get the supply required for daily consumption. I was of the opinion that when we got our gasoline launch that we might be able to use it sometimes for this purpose, but it is really too good to be messed up with fish and would cost so much in the way of gasoline fuel that I do not think it should be used for that purpose."

If you will kindly give these requirements your earliest consideration I shall be deeply obliged.

I remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

T.B. Westgate

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I am not at all satisfied about our fire escape system. We have a lot of small children in school. Would it be alright to put doors through the dormitory wall leading out to where the proposed veranda would be. This veranda will have to come, as it is the only proper means of fire escape for our building. Until we are authorized to build it, we would put up ladders from the proposed door to the ground. Please let me know regarding this matter.

Yours faithfully,

(sgd) Chas. F; Hives.
Principal.
Lac la Ronge, Sask.
Oct. 12, 1923.

Rev. T.B.R. Westgate, D.D.,
Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.,
Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I have this day received orders from the Department of Indian Affairs to build new chimneys. The have left the mode of construction and choice of material to my discretion. We cannot do anything towards it until we get material from town in the way of cement. I am very sorry that the grant for building veranda has not gone through, and would earnestly beg you to place before the Department the absolute importance this erection is as a means of fire escape. At the present time we have no adequate means of fire escape for our children, and we have a great number of little ones. A thousand dollars would do the job, because Mr. Mayo would look after the construction of it. We would get to work at it as soon as we received authority. Please Doctor Westgate place this appeal for the veranda as a necessary means of fire escape very strongly.

Now as we cannot build our new chimneys before the spring, and not being properly equipped as to a fire escape, and also having a school full of children, I think we had better start with a night watchman on the first of November, and continue with one for the five months instead of the four. Kindly let me know what you think of this.

Yours faithfully,

(sgd) Chas F. Hives.

November 14, 1923.

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

Two years ago a new main building was completed at the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School, 125 miles north of Prince Albert, Sask. The structure is a frame building, 3 stories high, and has never been provided with fire escapes. The Rev. Principal and the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada have strongly urged the erection of a verandah along the front of the building. It is considered that this addition would be the most satisfactory manner of securing adequate fire escapes from the dormitories. The Rev. Principal is prepared to supervise the work, if done by day labour, and he has estimated that the cost will be $1000.

I am favourably disposed towards granting this request and I shall be pleased to have your authority to incur the expense. Funds are available in the vote for Indian Education.

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.
November 14, 1923.

Dear Dr. Westgate:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, enclosing a copy of a communication from the Rev. Principal of the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School, with reference to the desirability of arranging for a verandah for the main building. I have noted that verandahs are necessary to the building of suitable fire escapes and that the Principal will undertake the work, if a grant of $1000 is allowed.

In reply I wish to authorize you to have this work carried out, under the direction of the Rev. Principal, without delay. A structure in keeping with the building should be erected. Competitive prices should be secured for the lumber and other materials that are purchased and proper time sheets, in duplicate, should be kept by the Principal, if it is necessary to hire any labour. When the bills for the material are presented, they should be supported by an Abstract of Tender form, showing the firms asked to quote and the prices quoted. The work should be done as economically as possible and the estimate of $1000 should not be exceeded. Will you please give directions to the Rev. Principal.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.

This building, which is situated about 100 yards from the main school building, has not been used to any great extent - if at all - for hospital purposes.

As the new School is provided with infirmaries there does not appear to be much likelihood of its being further required in that way. It is, moreover, too small to be of any great service as a hospital in an emergency such as an epidemic of influenza, and on such an occasion it would serve a more useful purpose as a place of rest for members of the staff who would have to nurse the sick. If not occupied it stands in danger of going entirely out of repair after the manner of the one at the Mackay School at The Pas. The total cost of fitting it up for a Principal's residence would not exceed $1000.00.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I have to bring to your notice the condition of some of the floors of our school. As you are aware, native Spruce lumber was used throughout in building, and in places this is worn so badly that it will have to be renewed next year. Two years seems to be a very short life, and yet two years seems to be the limit where there is very much traffic. When renewing, it would certainly pay to use hardwood. If five or six hundred dollars were spent each year in purchasing hardwood for flooring; it would take only three years to go through the whole building, and a fairly permanent job would be made. Some of the floors are in a bad state. On account of their being so rough, they hold the dirt, which when swept causes a very unsanitary state throughout the building. This aspect should be placed before the Department when writing them about this matter. I would also point out that some of the main rooms are still in an unfinished state. They require paint and Kalsomine. We should require about four hundred dollars for this. The exterior of the building should be repainted next year also. It required about forty gallons of paint for this.

Yours faithfully,

(sgd) Chas. F. Hives.
Principal.
Toronto, Ontario, Dec. 4, 1923,
41-43 The Bible House,
Alexander Ave., Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Sir,

RE CEMENT FLOOR FOR BASEMENT LAC LA RONGE SCHOOL.

With further reference to your letter of Sept. 28 (No. 132-2-5) in re the cost of a cement floor for the basement of the Lac la Ronge main school building, I beg to state that in a letter just received from the Principal (dated Nov. 1923) he estimates that fourteen (14) tons of cement will be required. In this connexion I may say, for your information, that after carefully discussing with your representative, Mr. Inspector Bunn of this city, the question of utilizing some other flooring material instead of cement, we came to the conclusion that the cement would be the most satisfactory, and the most economical in the long run. Mr. Inspector Bunn recommends that the cement be purchased direct from the Canada Cement Company, Winnipeg, and I am fully prepared to support this recommendation. In order that you might be able to estimate the total cost I asked the Canada Cement Co. for current prices, and received the following quotations:

1 bbl. of 350 lbs (or 4 bags of 87½ lbs ea.) $4.45
(If Mr. Inspector Bunn were authorized to purchase the cement he might be able to get it at a lower rate.)

If the bags are returned 20¢ is allowed for each, and a further reduction of 10¢ per bag is made for ready cash, thus bringing the purchase price down to $3.35 per bbl., or a total cost of $1072.00 for the 14 tons.

Of the freight from Winnipeg to Prince Albert I have no certain knowledge. The freight from Prince Albert to Lac la Ronge should be reckoned at the rate of $3.50 per hundred lbs., thus making the cost of freighting the 14 tons aggregate about $980.00
With regard to the freighting from Prince Albert, I may say that our Society has a contract with the Indian, Wm. Bear, and this was the rate at which we paid him last year. In the letter from the Principal already referred to, he states that the Revillon Freres are paying a white man named R. D. Brooks at the rate of $3.75 per 100 lbs. freightage this year. I should like to recommend that the contract be given to the Indian as he is a reliable man, and can handle it.

As all the cement is put up in bags (87½ lbs) it should go through to the school during the winter months, in order to escape as much as possible damage from moisture. The earlier, therefore, the order can be placed, the better chance there will be for the freighting to be done before the roads break up in the spring.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

TBRW/FEC.
Ottawa, December 12, 1923.

Reverend Sir:

I have to refer to the communication of the Deputy Superintendent General, dated the 19th ultimo, relative to verandahs at the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. It has been drawn to my attention that the proposed verandahs should not extend across the front of the building, because of the effect it would have on the lighting of the rooms. You should instruct the principal that the structures which are to be primarily for fire escapes should be at the ends of the building.

I have your letter of the 4th instant, relative to a cement floor in the basement of the Lac la Ronge institution. Before the Department gives consideration to the expenditure, you should state whether there are any drainage arrangements in the basement and what use is to be made of it, if properly floored.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:-

In reply to your letter of Dec.12 (132-2-5) concerning fire escapes and cement floor in the basement of the school at Lac la Ronge, I beg to state that I am referring this communication to the Principal for further details. It will, of course, take some time to receive his reply, but I think it necessary to do this as your instructions with regard to the fire escapes being placed at the ends of the building do not appear to me to be the best arrangement. Before making any further suggestion to you on this point I should like to consult the Principal.

Your further instruction that the proposed verandahs should not extend across the front of the building because of the effect it would have on account of the lighting of the rooms is one which will bring keen disappointment to the Principal and the staff as it now brings to me. As the class-rooms are at the ends of the building and are well lighted, a lower front verandah extending between the projecting ends where these are situated, would not be affected, and would be of immense comfort to the staff and the children. But I shall forward to you the opinion of the Principal in this connection when it comes to hand.

With regard to the basement, this at present is simply of dry earth, the bottom of the area which was excavated for the building. The furnace is there, and a good deal of fire wood will be kept there during the winter months. The engine, dynamo, and batteries are there, and it is difficult to keep these clean without a harder floor. On account of the inadequate space set apart for a laundry with a school of 100 children, part of the basement has to be used for that purpose throughout the winter months. These are some of the reasons why a good floor, preferably one of cement, is necessary, and although I shall
The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs.

shall write to you again when I hear from the Principal, I beg to give you this information now so that you may, if you think well, order the cement in time for it to be sent through before the trails break up in the spring.

With regard to the drainage arrangements, I may say that a very good septic tank has been installed, and was giving, at the time of my visit last year, every satisfaction. Any further drainage which may be necessary could be installed without incurring any very heavy expenditure.

Believe me,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir:

GASOLINE ENGINE FOR LAC LA RONGE SCHOOL.

The Principal of our Society's School at Lac la Ronge has presented me with a very urgent request for a gasoline engine for cutting wood. Our Society has already supplied the school with a pole saw, but in order to provide the vast amount of wood required it has been necessary for the school staff to borrow an engine from the Manager of the Hudson's Bay Post at that point. Such an arrangement is altogether unsatisfactory both to the school and to our Society, and I shall be grateful indeed if your Department will kindly furnish us with the engine required.

The Principal recommends a 6 horse power throttle governed kerosene engine, and points out that one of these if purchased from The T. Eaton Co., Winnipeg, (No. 441H-308) could be landed at Lac la Ronge at a total cost of $256.50.

I shall be obliged, therefore, if you will give this request favourable consideration, and remain,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary M.S.C.C.

[Signature]

Verry Poor Copy

Dear Doctor Westgate:

Referring to your letter of Dec. 28, re laundry, I am, under separate cover, enclosing plans of the present building, in case you have not them in the office. My idea was to extend the wing which accommodates the present laundry, and make the proposed new laundry 20 x 28 ft. This to have a basement similar to the basement under the main part. To be connected with the main basement by a passage way, and to be heated with a pipeless furnace. This would have a room upstairs which would be used as a drying room, which would be connected with the present drying which could be used as an ironing room. The whole of the ground floor would be the laundry proper, and should be sufficiently large enough. Outside of proper laundry equipment we would require boiler connected with the stove, for the purpose of supplying sufficient hot water for the laundry. In a previous letter I suggested using the present laundry for a bake room. I really think this would be a great convenience for us. Our kitchen is small for a school of our pupilage, and it would relieve the congestion during busy time in the kitchen.

Yours faithfully,

(sgd) Chas. F. Hives.

Principal.
Extract from letter from Mr. Hives dated Jan. 13, 1924.

"Re proposed laundry:- I do hope this goes through this year. I sent in to you last year a proposition to convert the present laundry into a bake room. Since getting in so many more pupils, and now that we are to have another teacher, I think we can improve on the proposition by converting the present kitchen into a kindergarten room, and having the present laundry as a kitchen. This would make an excellent kitchen. Then I would propose that the partition between the dining room and present kitchen be made of collapsible doors, so that at such times as Christmas the two rooms could be turned into one large assembly room. I am enclosing a list of what we would require in case the grant should go through."
Toronto, Ontario, Feb. 14, 1924,

Ottawa, Feb. 26, 1924.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 14th instant, requesting the Department to purchase for the use of the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School a gas engine for cutting wood. I should be pleased if you would indicate why the engine which the Department supplied two years ago cannot be used for this purpose. This engine was formerly used for pumping water and was referred to in your communication of January 26, 1923.

I have also your letter of the 14th instant, relative to your request for a cement floor in the basement and a laundry addition in the case of the same school. I have noted the enclosures and in reply I wish to suggest an arrangement which, if satisfactory to you, might be given favourable consideration by the Department. Will the Rev. Principal purchase, after securing competitive prices, the necessary windows, doors, shingles, paper and hardware for the laundry addition and erect same on a 20' x 28' basement; will he purchase, after securing competitive prices, two tubs and two hand washers for the laundry, two kitchen sinks complete with piping, a laundry stove and a pipeless furnace with necessary leads and floor registers; will he purchase, after securing competitive prices, sufficient cement for the laundry basement and for the floor of the laundry; will he arrange for the necessary lumber and labour and ensure an addition in keeping with the rest of the building - all provided that the Department pay accounts for materials and freight up to $1500? If so, you should communicate with the Department and your request will receive favourable consideration. I wish to inform you that two small, inexpensive hand washers are suggested as a large cylindrical washer is not considered suitable for an Indian residential school so distant from a freight office. It is considered that if the Department allows this addition and improvement, it would not be wise to try to cement the entire basement floor at this time.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Sir:

I herewith enclose account from Manville Hardware,
Prince Albert for cement etc., for construction of
chimneys in our school. Quotations from three firms
also enclosed. After carefully considering the various
ways of building the chimneys, I came to the conclusion
that cement concrete blocks would be the most economical
and best. Brick was ruled out on account of the high
cost from freightage, and also the damage that would
be done to them in transit. By building them of stone
masonry would mean bringing in a highly paid man from
Prince Albert whose transportation charges would be
at least $150.00. The mortar would have to be made of
cement also. By building of cement concrete blocks,
we can do the work ourselves with the help of a
labourer. There will be very little more expense.

I am enclosing freightage charges on cement and barbed
wire which is to be used for reinforcement, and cleanout
doors. The contract for freighting was given to an
Indian, who is well worthy of any help that can be
given him in that respect. We hope to have the chimneys
completed early in the spring, and would be pleased
to have the Treaty Paying Agent inspect them while he
is here.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal.

Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I would place before you, for your consideration, the matter of moving our saw mill from its present location to one further away from the main school building. At present it is not more than one hundred and fifty feet away from the main school building, and almost directly in front, thereby spoiling the general appearance of the place. It is moreover a menace to the building on account of fire. There is always a great deal of inflammable material around a saw mill, and if this ever caught fire the school building would be in great danger. The building in which the sawing machinery is housed is only a very temporary affair, and will soon have to be rebuilt. I would point out to you the great value of having such an outfit here. Not only in connection with the school, but also for the Indians at Lac la Ronge and Stanley. They get all their lumber manufactured here, and are therefore able to build fairly decent houses. If we had a help of five hundred dollars, the plant could be moved, and the machinery placed on a good and permanent foundation, and under a safe roof. Would you therefore place this matter before the Department of Indian Affairs, and see if they would do something towards helping to move the plant, and housing it properly.

Yours faithfully,

(sgd) Chas. F. Rives.
Principal.
Toronto, Ontario, March 12, 1934,
41-45 The Bible House,
Alexander Ave., Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Sir:

RE MOVING THE SAW-MILL AT LAC LA RONGE

You will recollect that during my recent visit (Feb. 19) to your Department, I mentioned the necessity of having the saw-mill at Lac la Ronge moved to another site, and was requested to furnish you with a written statement in this connexion. In compliance with this request I enclose herewith a copy of a letter from the Principal dealing with this matter, and will be obliged if you will let me know if your Department will honour time sheets kept by the Principal in connexion with labour employed in the moving of this mill, to the amount specified, namely five hundred dollars ($500.00).

I may say that having visited this school I am in full agreement with the Principal's suggestion that the mill should be moved to a site further away from the school.

Dr. Westgate urges the Department to give favourable consideration to the request of the Principal of the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School, which refers to the moving of the saw-mill from its present site. The M. S. C. C. representative explained the matter to me during his recent visit. The saw-mill, which will soon have to be rebuilt, is 150 ft. almost directly in front of the main school building. The appearance of the institution is spoiled and there is danger of fire because of the inflammable nature of the materials in the mill. It is proposed to move it some 200 yards away, to place it on a permanent foundation and under a safe roof. The principal is prepared to undertake the work if the Department makes a grant of $500 for the labour which he will have to employ. May I have your instructions.

Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, March 30, 1924.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, with reference to the moving of the saw-mill at the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. The saw-mill should be moved at least 200 yards and should be placed on a permanent foundation and under a safe roof. The Principal should keep proper time sheets in duplicate for the labour employed and should submit them to the Department with receipts covering the payments to the labourers. Please instruct the Rev. Principal.

Rev.T.B.R.Westgate, D.D.,
Field Secretary MSSC.,
Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I have to acknowledge receipt of communication from Department of Indian Affairs re verandah for our school. I may say that we have already made extensive preparations in getting out logs &c. The main objection to building the verandah along the whole front of the main building seems to be the fear of shutting out the light. All the rooms affected would be staff rooms. No class-rooms or dormitories would in any way be affected. The building faces the south, and so the verandah would, in the summer, be an advantage in shading the windows. It would moreover be a great convenience to the whole school, as the projection caused by the two wings at the ends of the main building allow for ample space for sleeping porches, in case we may have pupils who require out of doors treatment. One other thing in favor for having a verandah along the whole length of the building is that it makes a very adequate and reliable fire escape. The staff, as well as the children, have to be considered. You will notice it provides a door issuing from the Principal's room. In case of fire at either end of the building, the staff would be able to run along the verandahs and open the doors leading into the dormitories. You will notice by the plan enclosed that the exit is by ladder. After thinking it over I have come to the conclusion that sliding poles will be better. I have not the least hesitation in saying that in every way the full verandah will be a great advantage over the partial ones and as appearances have to be considered, the full verandah will make a very imposing structure.

In case the Department view this proposal with favor, which I sincerely hope they may, I am enclosing a list of material we shall require for the purpose. I received quotations on prices from Manville Hardware, and comparing these with T.Eaton Company, Manville Hardware, Prince Albert, is
below in price. He is also reliable. I therefore think it would be as well to order these at Manville Hardware as it will save time as well. The season is getting late and we shall have to make a move at once in order to get material here this winter.

The other part of letter is relative to cement floor for basement. I may say that the sewage pipes go along the basement floor, and that there are arrangements made in the pipe for drainage, in case we should ever get a cement floor.

I may say that if there is any choice in the matter of getting either the cement floor or new laundry, I would urgently advise choosing the laundry. In many ways the building of a new laundry will be a very valuable asset to our work. At present we have to use one of the playrooms for a class-room. This is very inconvenient, and is not fair to the children. If a new laundry is built the present kitchen could be converted into a very convenient class-room, and use the present laundry as a kitchen. I explained all this in a previous letter, and enclosed list of requirements for building. A new laundry is very necessary to the successful working of this institution.

Yours faithfully,

CHARLES F. HIVES.
Principal.
La la Rorge, Sask.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

Regarding the Gasoline Engine for sawing: The engine that was used for pumping, and which has been spoken of as likely to be used for sawing, is a very small engine 1/2 horse power, which is far too small for working a saw. At present this engine is doing good work, driving the laundry washing machine. If it is decided to purchase the engine for us, I would suggest that it be shipped to Montreal Lake as soon as possible, and it might possibly get here, as the ice will be on the lakes for some time.

Yours faithfully,

"Chas F. Hives"
Principal.

Sir:

Enclosed herewith please find Return of labour and vouchers for work executed and for logs bought for the removing and reinstalling and erecting of sawing mill. I may say that the place chosen is two hundred and fifty yards away from the former site, and that much further away from the school building. The building is set on cement pillars with a floor space of 15 ft by 60 ft for the main building and an engine room 12 ft by 18 ft. The building is sheeted with ship lap lumber, and the roof is covered with rubberoid. I beg to assure you that every cent of the $500.00 has been well spent, and except that the biggest part of the labour in building is executed by us without any extra cost of outside labour, there would not have been such a good building as there is.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

VERANDAH ETC. FOR LAC LA RONDE SCHOOL.

With further reference to the Deputy Superintendent General's letter of November 19 (132-2-5) your letter of December 12 and my reply of December 17, I beg to enclose herewith a statement which I have just received from the Principal in this connection.

I beg to enclose also a sketch of the proposed verandah which will help you to realize that it will not greatly interfere with the lighting of the rooms on that side of the building and will be of immense benefit in other ways.

If your Department decides to have the verandahs constructed in accordance with the proposed suggestions herewith submitted and will authorize me to procure the materials mentioned on the enclosed list from the Prince Albert firm I shall do my utmost to have them forwarded through to the School so that the work of construction may be carried on this summer.

I have the honour to be

Sir

Your obedient servant,

T.B.W./IMC.

Field Secretary M.S.C.C.
Lac la Ronge, Sask.
Feb.15, 1924,

Rev.T.B.R.Westgate, D.D.,
Field Secretary MSCC.,
Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I have to acknowledge receipt of communication from Department of Indian Affairs re verandah for our school. I may say that we have already made extensive preparations in getting out logs &c. The main objection to building the verandah along the whole front of the main building seems to be the fear of shutting out the light. All the rooms affected would be staff rooms. No class-rooms or dormitories would in any way be affected. The building faces the south, and so the verandah would, in the summer, be an advantage in shading the windows. It would moreover be a great convenience to the whole school, as the projection caused by the two wings at the ends of the main building allow for ample space for sleeping porches, in case we may have pupils who require out of doors treatment. One other thing in favor for having a verandah along the whole length of the building is that it makes a very adequate and reliable fire escape. The staff, as well as the children, have to be considered. You will notice it provides a door issuing from the Principal's room. In case of fire at either end of the building, the staff would be able to run along the verandahs and open the doors leading into the dormitories. You will notice by the plan enclosed that the exit is by ladder. After thinking it over I have come to the conclusion that sliding poles will be better. I have not the least hesitation in saying that in every way the full verandah will be a great advantage over the partial ones and as appearances have to be considered, the full verandah will make a very imposing structure.

In case the Department view this proposal with favor, which I sincerely hope they may, I am enclosing a list of material we shall require for the purpose. I received quotations on prices from Manville Hardware, and comparing these with T.Eaton Company, Manville Hardware, Prince Albert, is
below in price. He is also reliable. I therefore think it would be as well to order these at Manville Hardware as it will save time as well. The season is getting late and we shall have to make a move at once in order to get material here this winter.

The other part of letter is relative to cement floor for basement. I may say that the sewage pipes go along the basement floor, and that there are arrangements made in the pipe for drainage, in case we should ever get a cement floor.

I may say that if there is any choice in the matter of getting either the cement floor or new laundry, I would urgently advise choosing the laundry. In many ways the building of a new laundry will be a very valuable asset to our work. At present we have to use one of the playrooms for a class-room. This is very inconvenient, and is not fair to the children. If a new laundry is built the present kitchen could be converted into a very convenient class-room, and use the present laundry as a kitchen. I explained all this in a previous letter, and enclosed list of requirements for building. A new laundry is very necessary to the successful working of this institution.

Yours faithfully,

CHARLES F. HIVEB.
Principal.

Ottawa, April 7, 1924.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the first instant, with reference to verandahs at the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. The Department will agree to the erection of verandahs, as indicated in the plan you enclosed, if you and the Rev. Principal are willing to interfere with the sunlight for the staff rooms that will be affected. I cannot agree that galvanized iron sliding poles would be satisfactory and I have to instruct you to build a staircase from the top to the bottom verandah at each end of the structure.

Please be guided by the Deputy Superintendent General's letter of November 19th, last, when you are securing materials and arranging for labour. The Department cannot allow more than $1,000 in connection with the undertaking. The letter from the Manville Hardware Company is returned herewith.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Gentlemen:

Replying to your letter of the 9th instant, regarding payment of your account for the battery cells shipped to Rev. C. F. Hives, Principal, Indian Residential School, Lac la Ronge, I beg to inform you that the account which you were requested to send to the Reverend Principal, in order that he might certify the same upon arrival of the goods, has not yet been received by the Department. It is presumed that you forwarded your account, as requested, to the Principal, but that, owing to the mail facilities from that point during the winter months, there has been delay in his forwarding the same to the Department. As soon as the account is received, payment will be made. We are writing the Principal today, requesting him to certify the account and forward it as soon as possible. We regret the delay, but it is impossible to make payment until the account has been received, properly certified, by the Department.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have to refer to Dr. Scott's letter of the 16th instant, relative to the building programme for the Prairie Provinces. You will note that there is an item for the Lac La Ronge Indian Residential School. In this connection I have to inform you that it is proposed to make alterations to the old hospital building, so that it can be utilized as a principal's residence. It was the intention of the Department to authorize Dr. Westgate, of Winnipeg, to proceed with this work and you might find it advisable to correspond with him. When authority is being given for the purchase of any materials that are necessary, care should be taken to see that the regulations governing purchases are kept in mind.

Yours very truly,

J. D. McLean,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Dear Sir:

-- RE LAC LA RONGE C.OF E. SCHOOL. --

With further reference to your letter of March 29, (No.132-2-5) concerning the expenditure which may be incurred this year at our Society's Indian Residential School at Lac la Ronge, you state as follows:

"the Department has already authorized the expenditure of $500 for the purpose of moving the saw-mill and is prepared to give favorable consideration to an expenditure of $1,900 in connection with a cement floor and laundry addition at the school".

A copy of this letter was forwarded to the Principal for his information, and he has expressed to me his fear, based on the wording of your letter, that you are expecting him not only to build the laundry, but also to put down a cement floor in the school for the sum of $1,900.

As the building of the laundry will require a good deal, if not all of the $1,900, it is quite clear that the two works mentioned cannot be undertaken for the sum specified. The building of the laundry therefore will be pushed forward with all the vigour possible this summer, and I trust that the expenditure incurred in this connexion, up to, but not exceeding the sum of $1,900, will be met by your Department, and I shall be glad to have a statement from you to this effect. If the full sum is not required, I can assure you it will not be spent.
The cement floor in the basement cannot be undertaken this year, but should be done not later than the summer of 1925. In order to do this, the cement should be sent in during the freighting season of next winter.

I remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary M.S.O.C.

TBRW/X.
Ottawa, June 28, 1934.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 24th instant, regarding the expenditure authorized in building a laundry and cement floor at the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. It is noted that the amount authorized, viz.: $1900, will be required in the erection of the laundry building. An expenditure up to but not exceeding this amount may be used for the construction of the laundry building. Properly certified vouchers in duplicate, with receipted accounts attached for the cost of the material and labour, should be forwarded when the work has been completed.

Regarding the cement floor in the basement, no funds can be provided this year for the purpose, but this requirement will be noted for our next year's Estimates. You may inform the principal of the amount available for the building of the laundry, viz.: $1900.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. T.B.R. Westgate, D.D.,
Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.,

Dear Sir:

With further reference to your letter of May 2 (No 132-2-5) relative to the shipping of kerosene engine for our Society's School at Lac la Ronge, I beg to state that I referred this matter to the Principal for his opinion as to whether we should have this shipped during the summer, and in his reply, which has just come to hand, he expresses the hope that it may be forwarded to Prince Albert during the summer, in readiness for transportation to the school with the first loads of freight when the freighting season opens, as it is most urgently required during the first part of the winter. I shall be glad therefore, if you will have the engine shipped at your earliest convenience, consigned to the Rev. C.F. Hives, Principal Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School, Care of Messrs. Revillon Freres, Prince Albert, who will receive it and give it careful storage until the freighting season opens.

Believe me, Sir

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, with further reference to the supplying of a 6 horse power throttle-governed kerosene engine for the use of the Lac La Ronge Indian Residential School.

In reply I beg to inform you that we are requesting Mr. John R. Bunn, Inspector of Indian Agencies, Winnipeg, to obtain competitive prices and arrange for the purchase and shipment of this engine to Rev. C. F. Hives, c/o Messrs. Revillon Freres, Prince Albert, Sask. Mr. Bunn has been requested to consult you and to ascertain definitely the type of engine which should be obtained.

Your obedient servant,

41-43, The Bible House,

Ottawa, July 8th, 1924.

Sir:

The Department desires to obtain for the use of the Lac La Ronge Indian Residential School, Lac La Ronge, Sask., a 6 horse power throttle-governed kerosene engine for delivery care of Messrs. Revillon Freres, Prince Albert, Sask. Rev. Dr. Westgate, the Field Secretary of the Missionary Society of the Church of England, 41-43 The Bible House, Winnipeg, has made a request for this engine.

It is considered that Winnipeg would be a good centre in which to obtain competitive prices, and I shall be pleased if you will undertake the purchase and delivery of this engine. You might consult Dr. Westgate and ascertain full particulars as to the type of engine required. You should then obtain competitive prices from a number of dealers, and place the order with the firm quoting you the lowest price F.O.B. Prince Albert, Sask., sales tax included. Dr. Westgate has forwarded a quotation from the T. Eaton Co., Winnipeg, for an engine of the above mentioned horse power, their Catalogue No. 441M-308. When the purchase has been made, you should arrange to have the engine shipped, complete, to Rev. C. F. Hives, Principal, Lac La Ronge Indian Residential School, c/o Messrs. Revillon Freres, Prince Albert, Sask.

You should obtain an account, in duplicate, from the firm from whom you make the purchase, and you will be good enough to certify the same and forward it to the Department for payment. You should also forward an abstract of the tenders received, showing the firms asked to quote and the prices quoted.

We hope that you will be able to arrange for the purchase and shipment of this engine at an early date.

Your obedient servant,

J. R. Bunn, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Chambers of Commerce,
Winnipeg, Man.

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Boarding School,

Aug. 14, 1924.

Sir:

According to your instructions received by letter No. 132-25 of Sept. 25, 1923 I have had built new chimneys in place of the ones which were condemned in our school. These chimneys, four in all have all been pulled down, and new ones built of good cement concrete. There is a separate flue for each furnace or stove, and the tops of the chimneys are finished off in keeping with the rest of the building. In all the work special attention was paid in making them fire proof. Proper iron cleanout doors were built in the base, so that they will be kept clean conveniently. According to your instructions I engaged a man to do this work. As I was able to get a competent man right here, there will be no travelling expenses to pay. I engaged him by the month, and we supplied any extra help necessary.

I herewith enclose return of labour, trusting that you may find it in order,

Your obedient servant,

Chas. F. Stevens
Principal.
Lac la Ronge, Sask.

Labour employed and logs used in removing and re-erecting sawmill at Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. The mill was removed a distance of 250 yards from the former site which was too near school building. The new building is set on cement pillars with a floor space of 60'x15' for the main building, and an engine room 12'x18'. The building is sheeted with shiplap lumber and the roof covered with rubberoid roofing material. The Hudson's Bay Company advanced the wages to the men employed and also to McAuley Bros. for logs delivered. A cheque in payment of the account should be drawn in favour and sent to the Hudson's Bay Co., Lac la Ronge, Sask.

Sir:

I herewith enclose Return of labour on Verandah of our school. Which work was sanctioned by you.

I beg to say that this work is now complete and am enclosing a snap taken since the erection, which will show our work, and hope that you may feel that the addition is an improvement to the looks of the building. I assure you that it is a great convenience, and makes a splendid fire escape. Great care throughout has been exercised in both workmanship and strength, so that it is thoroughly in keeping with the rest of the building. The front of the building on the ground floor was stripped of siding, and selected V joint put in its place. This is painted white with stained and varnished trimings. The roof has good quality sheet Gal. iron properly rolled by a competent tin smith, and soldered. The exterior is painted in keeping with the rest of the building.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal.

The following letters from Mr. Hives dated Sept. 13 and Sept. 15, 1924, will explain the necessity for the requirements specified.

Lac la Ronge, Sask.,
Sept. 13, 1924.

Rev. T.B.R. Westgate, D.D.,
Field Secretary M.S.C.C.
Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I am enclosing a list of our most urgent needs for next year.

Cement for basement floor:
This will be a big job, and should not, I think, all be attempted in one year, because the expense will be great, and there are other things that must be dealt with, and also because we shall have to do the work ourselves. I think it will be a little too much for us to tackle in one year. If we asked for three tons of cement for this time, and do as far as it will go, and then complete the job another year.

Flooring for main rooms in building:
I spoke of this last year. The floors in the main rooms are getting very badly worn, and should, in many places be renewed. Hardwood flooring would be the more lasting and sanitary. The building is worth a good floor. Five thousand square feet of flooring would renew floors in all main rooms.

Paint for Building:
The outside of the building was painted two years ago, and should have another coat now. Twenty four gallons of paint would be required for this work. Twenty of pearl grey, four of olive green. The inside of the building has not yet been completed. We need two hundred lbs. of white lead, twenty gallons of boiled oil, five gallons of turps, five gallons of varnish, one dozen pound paint brushes, six dozen packages of Alabastine and three brushes for putting on same.

Batteries for light:
Last year the Department supplied us with a battery of sixteen cells. These we tried to connect as per instructions from Light people, but the old ones were too far gone to allow us doing this. We had, therefore to remove the old ones, and work with the new ones only. Now that our building is growing, and according to advice from the Delco Light people, we must have another set of sixteen cells, similar to the ones we received last year, if we are to retain satisfactory light. So far our light plant has not given the least trouble, and it has been steadily in operation for nearly three years. I do hope therefore that the Department will allow us this battery, and that it will come in as early as possible this winter.

Flush tanks for toilets:
The toilet flush tanks sets procured for our School in the first instance were of a very inferior quality, and have given a lot of trouble in the way of wasting water. We need half a dozen new sets to replace those we have.

In connection with our compression tank:
We were supplied five two inch valves for the purpose of getting water from different parts. There has always been a great waste of water.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6316, file 656-5, part 3)
to Prince Albert to be ground. The mechanic, to whom the valve was sent, said that it was the wrong kind of a valve. That it was a steam valve, and not a valve for a compression tank. The Department bought these tanks for us, and will know from whom they came. We should have these valves supplied as soon as possible. I have had to procure one in place of the one I sent down, and the cost of the new one is $13.50.

Our School pupilage has increased since the School was erected. We now have one hundred and six pupils, and have only four bath tubs for that number. I think we should have two more at least.

Septic tank:
We require thirty sacks of cement to construct a larger septic tank. The one we have does very well during the summer, but when the severe cold weather comes, it is not large enough.

While the treaty paying agent was here I spoke to him about a fireproof roof for our building. I do not know if he will do anything about it, but I rather think he will.

Now I think I have mentioned most of our urgent needs, and hope that they may be granted.

Yours faithfully,

(sgd.) Chas. F. Hives
Principal

Lac la Ronge, Sask.
Sept. 15, 1924

"Rev. T.B.R. Westgate, D.D.,
Field Secretary M.S.C.C.,
Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I have a very special request to make which I would be glad if it could be put through as soon as possible.

You will likely remember our fisherman's dwelling. Well it is a miserable affair, and a disgrace to the rest of our institutions. It was bad enough during the old days, but now it seems, and is entirely out of place. Moreover it is unfit for any man to live in. It is built of logs, and is not weather proof by any means. We have to have a separate dwelling for the Fisherman. Firstly because the present one, who is more or less of a permanency, as he is married to a native of this part, has a family, and secondly it is better to have the fish cleaning away from the school building.

Would you please try and get us six hundred dollars to put up a place for a fisherman's house. That is not a very large sum, but it is sufficient, and we can do very well on that amount.

I would be very glad if this could be negotiated before the cold weather comes.

Yours faithfully,

(sgd.) Chas. F. Hives
Principal"

Sir:

I enclose herewith accounts and Returns of labor on New Laundry at our School. The work is progressing very satisfactorily under the existing circumstances. As news of the grant came too late to enable us getting in hardware for building, we have had to get same from store here, and take them at their price. The greatest care has been taken throughout in the building. The basement is on the same level as the rest of the buildingbasement, and the walls of same are built with stone and mortar as the other walls are built. And in fact the addition is quite in keeping with the rest of the building.

Dear Sir;

With further reference to my letter of October 30th last, addressed to the Deputy Superintendent General and Section II, on Page 4 of the list of requirements for our Society's Schools for the coming year, I beg to state that the Rev. C.F. Rives, Principal, Lac la Ronge School who is now in Winnipeg, has brought to my attention, the very urgent need of the 16 Battery Cells for the Delco Lighting System referred to in his letter of September 13th, copy of which was attached to my letter referred to above.

You will recollect (see your letter December 10th, 1923 No. 132-2-5) that 16 Battery Cells were forwarded to this school at the close of 1923, to supplement those already installed there. When the attempt was made to connect the new cells with the old ones, it was found to be quite impossible, as the old ones, being insufficient in number, were overtaxed, and as a result were practically worn out.

The same thing will probably happen to the Cells sent in in 1923, unless they are supplemented (before they have had much further use) by the 16 Battery Cells referred to in the correspondence above, and I write to call your attention to this important matter.
The Secretary,

and to ask that steps be taken for the purchase of these extra cells, and their transportation to the School, before the present freighting season closes.

Yours very truly,

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

In October, 1923, Dr. Westgate drew to our attention the worn-out condition of the batteries of the electric light plant at the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. Sixteen cells, costing $252.39, were sent to the school at that time, to supplement the 16 old cells. It is now reported that when they were connected up the old ones had to be discarded. It appears that 32 cells are required for the plant at the school, to prevent over-taxing.

I wish to recommend that 16 new cells be sent to the school, to be used with the present equipment so that satisfactory lighting will result. I fear that the present battery will be run down at an early date if it is not supplemented. The cost will be approximately $250.

Supt. of Indian Education.

Sir:

Hives, Principal of our Indian School at Lac la Ronge. I append herewith an extract from a letter received from Mr. Hives some time ago in connection with this matter.

"In connection with our compression tank:- With the tanks were supplied five two inch valves for the purpose of closing off the water from different parts. There has always been a leakage through these valves, causing trouble from freezing in the winter. This summer I had one taken out, and sent down to Prince Albert to be ground. The mechanic, to whom the valve was sent, said that it was the wrong kind of a valve. That it was a steam valve, and not a valve for a compression tank. The Department bought these tanks for us, and will know from whom they came. We should have these valves replaced as soon as possible. I have had to procure one in place of the one I sent down. And the cost of a new one is $13.50."

Trusting that the accounts may receive favourable consideration,

I have the honour to be

Sir:

I have to bring to your notice the matter of our sewage disposal system conditions, which is a constant menace to proper sanitary state and the good health of pupils and staff.

At present we have not a septic tank. When the school was built, there was no provision made for the construction of a septic tank, and although this matter was pointed out to the church authorities, (The school at that time being under the control of the Diocese of Saskatchewan,) the matter was not considered to be of much importance.

With a school pupilage of fifty or sixty as in the old days, it would be possible for a cesspool to handle the disposal, but we have double that number of pupils in at the present time, and if we had the accommodation etc., it would be an easy matter to get half as many again pupils at short notice. A cesspool, therefore, is not capable of handling the sewage from our school without a great deal of filthy work and without being a constant menace to our whole system.

Up to the present time we have been able to look after this matter by being constantly on the watch in attending to the cesspool. But this is no easy matter during the winter months. And now that we have such a large pupilage, the matter becomes more acute.

If a properly constructed septic tank were adopted, we should have no difficulty in our sewage disposal. What we require is enough cement, the actual septic tank connections, the necessary tile for liquefying after leaving chamber of septic tank, and a man to look after the work.

Treaty Paying Agent saw the present system last July, and could give you information regarding the same.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd) Chas. F. Hives.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith a copy of a letter from the Principal of our Society's school at Lac la Ronge setting forth the necessity of having a septic tank installed at that institution.

On page 4 in the List of Requirements which accompanied my letter to the Deputy Superintendent General on the 30th of Oct. last, you will find this item mentioned under the Lac la Ronge School and a further reference made to it on page 8 of that same list where the Principal stated as follows:-

"We require thirty sacks of cement to construct a large septic tank. The one we have does very well during the summer but when the severe cold weather comes it is not large enough."

As the construction of a proper septic tank sufficient for an institution of not less than 110 children and a staff of 12 is a matter of first rate importance to this institution, I beg to request that steps be taken to have the same completed before the beginning of next winter. You will notice from the second last paragraph in the enclosed letter that in order to have this accomplished the following are required:

(1) A quantity of cement; (2) Septic tank connections; (3) Tile; (4) A man to do the work.

While special stress is laid by the Principal in the enclosed letter on the indispensable necessity of having the septic tank provided this year I beg to direct your attention to the other items therein mentioned and to request that those which have not yet been furnished should be supplied during the coming fiscal year.

With regard to the cement floor in the basement I understand from your letter of June 28, 1924 (132-2-5), that provision would be made for this purpose in the ensuing year's
estimates and I greatly hope that this provision has not been overlooked.

Believe me, sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Field Secretary M.S.C.C.
Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Bake Oven for Lac la Ronge, Sask:

Dear Sir:

The Principal of our Society's school at Lac la Ronge in a letter just received from him calls my attention to the great inconvenience which he and his staff are suffering on account of the lack of a proper bake oven for that institution.

In his letter, which is dated Feb. 11th, he states that the oven which was supplied was too small in the first place even for the attendance of pupils only about half the number of those at present enrolled, and this being the case it is altogether too small for a school of the present size and with the greatly increased enrollment.

As a lack of a proper bake oven means a waste of flour and as this is one of the heaviest items of the expenditure which our Society has to meet at this remotely situated school, I shall be very much obliged if you will take steps to have a suitable bake oven provided at your earliest convenience.

Believe me, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary M.S.C.C.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,
REGINA, SASK., March 23rd, 1925.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to inform you that on the 16th of April 1924 you submitted a list of work that was to be done on the various schools in Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta, and pointed out that in no case should the amount set opposite the work be exceeded.

On the 24th of the same month, your letter #132-2-5, you wrote again, referring to your letter of the 16th, and pointed out that there was an item for the Lac la Ronge Residential School, that it was the intention of the Department to authorize Dr. Westgate of Winnipeg to proceed with the work, and that I might find it advisable to correspond with him.

On receipt of this letter I took the matter up with Dr. Westgate, and pointed out to him that authority had been granted to expend $1000.00 in making alterations at the Lac la Ronge School. I again wrote to him on the 13th of August on the same subject. He replied saying that he wished to expend the $1000.00 in re-modelling the old hospital into a Principal's residence. I gave him authority to do this; at the same time pointing out that the authority was for only $1000.00. He replied to me on the 20th of August, saying that the work would be carried out by his Mr. Hives, and the sum would not exceed $1000.00.

Duncan G. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6316, file 656-5, part 3)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Later on, under date of January 17th, I received a letter from Dr. Westgate, saying that they had changed all their former plans, and had decided to build a new residence for the Principal, as they could not make the alterations on the old hospital. He assured me in that letter that they would not exceed the $1000.00 sanctioned by me, and went on to say, if Mr. Hives does not use the whole of this sum in building the new residence he would be glad if I would authorize him to spend the balance in providing equipment. This I would not authorize until I had a list submitted, showing how much money he had saved, and what equipment he proposed to purchase with same. This list he never furnished.

I am today in receipt of a report and vouchers sent direct to me by Mr. Hives, in which you will notice that he has exceeded his authority by $735.14, and I wish to point out to the Department that I take no responsibility in connection with this matter. Dr. Westgate pointed out that Mr. Hives was a practical man, and as the Department instructed me to hand the work over to him, I had nothing further to say.

I did not call for the tenders, therefore, I have not signed the yellow sheets. I will, however, sign the vouchers, and it is for the Department to decide whether the amount of $735.14 is to be deducted or not.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
April 1, 1925.

MEMO FOR FILE:

I have made a study of the file for the past 15 months, with a view to learning what authority has been directed and what expenditure has been incurred in connection with plant and equipment at the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. This school has received quite favourable consideration. The accounts which Mr. Graham forwards under cover of his letter of the 23rd ultimo are alright as far as authority is concerned. We gave Dr. Westgate permission to expend $1900 on laundry. Accounts totalling $1199.15 have already been paid. Commissioner Graham had authority to expend $1000 in connection with the principal's residence at this school. The accounts totalling $1733.14, which he presents now, cover not only the principal's residence but the balance of the expense in connection with the laundry. The total authorization for both laundry and residence was $2900 and all bills amount to $2932.29. Although the expenditure should have been incurred earlier; in view of the distance of the school from the regular lines of communication, the accounts are only now all to hand.

Earlier correspondence presents the urgency of a fisherman's residence ($600) and painting and new flooring for the main building ($1000). These two items are being voted for 1925-26. Replacements to the water system and a fireproof roof have been noted for future estimates. $1600 will be available for the school this fiscal year. $250 has already been expended for urgent replacements to electric light battery. The Church authorities have also requested us to supply a bake oven and to build a larger septic tank. It may be that the management and Church authorities would prefer to have the last two activities undertaken and postpone, if necessary, the fisherman's residence and the painting and new floors for main building.

Ottawa, April 3, 1925.

Sir:

I have your No. 307-11A of the 23rd ultimo, enclosing accounts in connection with building activity at the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. I note that these accounts total $1733.14 and that some of the expenditure was in connection with the new laundry building.

In reply I have to inform you that during the fiscal year 1923-24 authority was directed for an expenditure of $1900 for a laundry building. Accounts totalling $1199.15 have already been paid and the extra expenditure shown on the vouchers you enclosed was the balance from the former authority. Cheques will be directed to the different firms in due course.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. M. Graham, R.S.O.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Ottawa, April 5, 1925.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, in which you request that a new bake oven be supplied for the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. I note that the present equipment is too small. In reply I regret to inform you that favourable consideration cannot be given, as our funds are extremely limited.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. T. B. R. Mastgate, D.D.,
Field Secretary, M. S. C. C.,
41-43 The Bible House,
Alexander Ave.,
Winnipeg, Man.
Ottawa, April 3, 1925.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, with reference to the advisability of installing a new septic tank at the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. In earlier correspondence, you have urged the provision of a fisherman's residence and the painting of the main building as well as some new flooring. There was an item included in the 1925-26 Estimates in this connection and I should now be pleased to learn from you which improvements you consider most urgent.

With reference to the last paragraph of your letter, I have to inform you that favourable consideration could not be given to placing an item for a cement floor to the basement in the Estimates, as it was doubtful if the expense of such an undertaking was warranted by the benefits to be derived.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. T. B. R. Westgate, D.D.,
Field Secretary, M. S. C. C.,
41-43 The Bible House,
Alexander Ave.,
Winnipeg, Man.
Lac la Bonge, Sask.
May 20, 1925.

Rev. T.B.R. Wentgate, D.D.,
Field Secretary, M.S.C.U.,
Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Doctor Wentgate:

Re yours of April 6th

I have thought over this letter very carefully, and will first of all deal with each item, and sum up with what I think is most important in the way of improvements.

Fisherman's Residence. I may say that we have pulled to pieces the old hospital building, and have put up a very compact and convenient house at a convenient site. If we could get the Department to give us $200.00 to finish this off in the way of paint etc., we should manage well. I explained to you and the Department, that the old hospital building was not at all fit for a principal's residence, and therefore we built an entirely new building on the same site, after pulling the hospital away. Then we thought of turning it into a fisherman's residence, but I concluded that it was not very suitable for such a purpose, and so, as it was made of rough lumber, I had it pulled to pieces, the lumber put through the planer, and we have built a very compact, and suitable house for the fisherman.

Cement for basement floor. If it will be any help towards getting the other requirements I am prepared to do my best to get along without this.

Hardwood flooring. I wonder if we could get this before the close of next trafficking season. That is by next March. This would cost in the neighborhood of $100.00.

Paint for buildings. This is very important, if we are to keep the buildings looking decent, and in a sanitary condition. I may say that a large portion of the interior has never received any paint or color wash on the walls, and that the part finished has been at the expense of the Commission.

Batteries for light plant. These have been supplied and so do not need to be dealt with.

Plugh tanks for toilets. This is very necessary. It is not a very large item, and should not cost more than $100.00. I would urge this.

Valves for compression. We shall not require these now, as we have moved our pump and engine into the basement, and therefore done away with danger from frost.

Septic tank. This is very necessary, and will be the most expensive item. This must be done for the sake of the sanitary conditions. At present it is a great abomination, as well as a great danger.
Fireproof roof for main building. I have been thinking this thing over, and believe that proper spark arrestors for the chimneys could be procured, and as we have done away with the kitchen chimney on main roof, the roof would be protected sufficiently.

First then is:
1. Septic tank.
2. Paint and color wash for building; -750
3. Flush tanks for 6 toilets.
4. $200.00 for finishing fishermen's house.
5. Spark arrestors for 4 chimneys.

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd) Chas. F. Hives,
Principal.
Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada

Dear Sir:

La Lo Ronge, C. of E. School,

With further reference to my letter of March 27th last, and your reply of April 3rd (132-2-5) relative to the improvements most urgently required at our Society's School at La Lo Ronge, I beg to state that the delay in communicating with you in this connexion is due to the fact that I considered it advisable to refer your letter to the Principal for his information, and for any suggestions or recommendations which he might wish to make.

His reply has just come to hand and you will please find a copy enclosed herewith. I would direct your attention to the summary given at the close and, beg to state, that the order, as given by the Principal, in which the improvements should be provided has my full approval. His remarks with regard to the installation of a septic tank in place of the cess pool now in use, are in no wise exaggerated. The situation is such that it would be difficult for any language to over-state it.

With regard to the conversion of the old hospital building into the Fisherman's residence, the action taken received the approval of your Commissioner.

Seeing that the Principal is willing not to press for the cement flooring for the basement I greatly hope that you may be able to provide the other improvements as requested.

Believe me, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

FIELD SECRETARY M.S.C.C.

Ottawa, June 6, 1925.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, with reference to the requirements of the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. I note that you and the Rev. Principal are of the opinion that a septic tank should be provided without delay. As you have been informed, certain funds are available for improvements at this school, but before a decision can be reached with reference to the other improvements, it will be necessary to learn just what the septic tank will cost. The Department Architect is prepared to draw a plan and issue instructions in connection with the installation of a septic tank when more information is to hand. Our officer should know the type and size of cesspool now in use and the nature of its materials. It may be possible to use it as the first chamber of a septic tank. It will also be necessary to have a plan of the grounds showing the position of the buildings, present cesspool, proposed septic tank and its outlet. The nature of the soil should be determined and the fall from the building indicated.

The septic tank will cost a considerable sum and it can be authorized only after sufficient thought has been given to the installation so that its success will be assured.

You are authorized to expend the sum of $300 for paint and other materials for the decorating of the main building and the finishing of the fisherman's cottage. The Department has been under heavy expense in connection with this school during the past few years, and I consider that your Society should be responsible for flush tanks for the toilets and spark arresters for the chimneys.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. T. B. R. Westgate, D. D.,
Field Secretary, M. S. C. G.,
41-43 The Bible House,
Alexander Ave.,
Winnipeg, Man.
The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

In connection with your letter of June 6th relative to the installation of a septic tank at the Lac la Ronge School, I beg to furnish you with the following information just received in a letter from the Principal dated June 29th. He writes, in part, as follows:

"RE THE DISPOSAL SYSTEM. The School stands on a south-east slope and facing that direction. The cesspool which is a hole in the ground lined with lumber lies sixty feet east of the building. As far as I can see that direction is the only available one for the septic tank. To the rear of the building, and also north-west the ground rises. The great disadvantage is that the school was built on a slope instead of on the top of the hill.

I do not think the cesspool would do for a first chamber. In fact it would cost more in time and cement to do anything with it than it would to construct an entirely new one. We can utilize the cesspool so as to handle the waste from the laundry, as I understand that the same counteracts the working of the septic tank.

While on the way down I had the good fortune to fall in with the contractor who did the work on the Elkhorn (Mr. Wyatt) and he gave me some very helpful suggestions regarding septic tanks. He said that a septic tank with double chambers each 6'x6'x6' would handle the disposal from our School. To construct this with concrete we would require 32 sacks of cement, which would cost $260.00 landed at Lac la Ronge. One hundred and fifty feet of soil pipe, costing $202.00 f.o.b. Lac la Ronge. Pig lead etc. for joints and extra labour..."
$200.00. The total cost I estimated would be $673.00. We have the actual septic tank connections, and cast iron man holes and covers. I can look after the work myself, and so do away with expert expense.

My suggestion is to construct the septic tank thirty feet from the building, the same to handle the bathroom and toilets. Not to have the laundry waste run into it, but to run latter into the cesspool from which it can be pumped when necessary. The outlet from the septic tank would also connect with this. From this cesspool we have drainage through the soil. I think if these suggestions are carried out we should have no difficulty with our disposal system.

The above information will, I trust, be sufficient for your purpose, but if there is any information which you desire I shall be glad to furnish it on receipt of your request.

I am deeply obliged to you for your authorization to expend the sum of $300.00 for paint etc for the decoration of the main building and the fisherman's cottage, and I have notified the Principal of this authorization and have asked him to undertake the work and submit an account with vouchers in the usual way.

Believe me, Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

TBRW/JF.
FIELD SECRETARY M.S.C.C.
Ottawa, July 10, 1925.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, with reference to a sewage disposal system at the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. The Department Architect considers that the scheme mentioned in the Rev. Principal's letter to you would be quite satisfactory and you are authorized to purchase, after securing competitive prices, 32 sacks of cement and 150 feet of soil pipe. I note that you estimate the cost of these materials will be $462 at Lac la Ronge, all freight costs paid. You may also authorize the Principal to expend the sum of $200 for expert or heavy labour. Labour returns in duplicate should be kept, showing the time of the men engaged and their receipts. Under separate cover, copies of labour return forms are being directed to you. Please see that no unnecessary expense is incurred in this connection.

Funds are available for a certain amount of flooring for the main building. The Department considers that e.g. fir is suitable for this purpose, and I should be pleased if you would make a recommendation as to the best method of expending $600 in this connection. It will be necessary to know whether expert labour is required and how much flooring is needed for the rooms that are in the worst condition.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.
