Dear Sir:

Last year, the Department very kindly made a grant towards the fixing up of the hospital building at the Boarding School at Lac la Ronge in order to make it fit for a Principal's residence. This was done, and a very comfortable residence has been built in every way in keeping with the school building. I regret to say, however, that we have very little furniture to put in it.

During the fire of five years ago, my wife and I lost all our personal property in the way of furniture, clothing etc., excepting what we happened to be wearing at the time. A few years previous to that I had bought furniture for our rooms in the school, and of course this was all lost.

If the Department could help towards buying furniture for the new residence, I assure you it would be greatly appreciated. A grant of five hundred dollars would purchase all the necessary furniture needed.

I am at present in Calgary, and would like to buy the furniture before I return to Lac la Ronge next month, as I do not expect to be in civilization again for three years after my return to work.

If the Department can possibly give this matter favorable consideration, would you kindly communicate this with Rev. T.B.R. Westgate, DD., our Field Secretary.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal,
Boarding School,
Lac la Ronge, Sask.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

With reference to Department's communication of July 10, relative to flooring for our school at Lac la Ronge. They stipulate the expenditure of $600.00 in this connection. I have made inquiries re best fir flooring, and find that it is worth $74.00 per thousand f.o.b. Prince Albert. That the weight per thousand is 2000 lbs. Which means another $60.00 so that it is worth $134.00 f.o.b. Lac la Ronge.

I would recommend therefore, that 4000, four thousand be procured, and also nails, paper, quarter round etc. We can do the work ourselves, and therefore do not require any expert labour. My assistant is an expert carpenter, and is well able to do the work properly.

This should be bought this fall, so that it may go in by the first freight teams.

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd) Chas. F. Hives.
Principal
Boarding School,
Lac la Ronge, Sask.

I must say that I received these prices from Cushing Bros., Saskatoon, who have always given very fair rates in our dealings with them. Also re flooring. I recommend that we should use the 4000 ft. of flooring on the floors that most need it, as far as it will go.
Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada

Sir:

I beg to submit herewith my report on the Annuity Payments throughout Ile a La Crosse Agency, Treaty No. 10 for 1925.

LAC LA RONGE.

The school was closing for holidays, in fact some of the children had already gone, so I did not examine the remaining pupils. I looked through their exercise book work and found it to compare favorably with Beauval school at La Plonge. I went through the school from basement to garret and found it clean and tidy. The basement is wet and needs a cement floor badly. The disposal system is bad and very unhealthy. The present system, as I saw it, is overflowing and lying on the surface of the ground evaporating, ans when the wind blows from the east the smell from this quarter is awful. In winter it freezes up and causes endless trouble. It has to be pumped out on the ground, and the stench might be better imagined than described. The Assistant Principal Mr. Mayo spoke of changing the disposal drain to a muskeg at the back of the school, but in my mind I think the result would be the same. This would overflow on this muskeg and when the wind blows from that quarter the smell would be as bad as it is now. The system is so poor that it cannot carry off all the refuse and children use a number of outhouses which adds to the smell. With a proper system which could carry off all refuse these outhouses could be dispensed with, and the school surroundings look much tidier. I would suggest a septic tank similar to that proposed for the Onion Lake School. This disposal system needs looking after at once, and I cannot urge too strongly the necessity of immediate action in the matter, if we would prevent an epidemic of some disease among the children in this school.

W. R. Taylor
Indian Agent.
Regina, Sask., Sept. 8th, 1925.

Sir:

I am enclosing herewith a long report on the Treaty 10 trip which was written by Mr. Indian Agent Taylor.

With regard to the drainage at the Lac la Ronge school. It seems to me the Department should take steps next year to put in a sewage disposal system here.

(Sgd.) W. M. Graham.

Sir:

Some of the members of my staff in our school here have very kindly made themselves responsible for the purchasing of a Victor Safety Cinema for the benefit of our children in school.

These children have never had the chance of seeing a town or any of the things that go to make up our civilization: Trains, cars, stone or brick houses and buildings. Our greatest hindrance in the work and development of the children here is ignorance. They know so little outside of their own life, and therefore their own people have the bigger influence on them, and for that reason the drag on our efforts towards their proper development is tremendous.

For this reason we have clubbed together and have raised enough to enable us to get the machine. The price being $160.00

As this is especially for the education of the Indian children, would the Department kindly pay the rentage on one dozen films monthly for six months in the year. I feel sure that this scheme will be a help towards the progress in the school, and help towards our fight against ignorance and superstition which is so prevalent amongst this people. I sincerely hope you may be able to give us some help towards supplying the necessary films.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Principal.

Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Mr. Hives, the Principal of our Society's School at Lac la Ronge has forwarded the attached letter to me for my approval before submitting the request it contains to you, and I beg to state that I shall be very grateful if you can help him in the way he suggests.

I may say that our Staff at the Mackay School, The Pas, Man, have also secured a safety moving picture machine, and some films were exhibited at the time of my recent visit which proved both interesting and instructive to the children. As the cost of the films at this School was being met by the School management, I should be very grateful if you will make a similar grant to meet the cost of these. The cost of the films at Lac la Ronge would be much greater than at the Mackay School owing to the greater distance and the correspondingly greater cost of carriage, but if your Department can make an annual grant say of $50.00 for the Mackay School and about $100.00 for Lac la Ronge, it would I think be sufficient.

Believe me, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

In a letter just received from the Rev. C.F. Hives, Principal of our Society's School at Lac La Ronge, he presents a very urgent request for a bake oven. His letter in part reads as follows:

"I sent a requisition for a bake oven last year, and pointed out to you how necessary this was. We have managed in a very poor way since that time to make the present one do, but we get a lot of very bad bread, and in fact it is an utter failure as a bake oven for such an Institution as ours. I would therefore urgently request that something be done to replace it with something decent." He has not mentioned the particular kind of bake oven which would be the most suitable, but as the School has a capacity of 100 children, I am of the opinion that an oven similar to the one installed in the Elkhorn School would be the most suitable. It should be borne in mind that the fuel used in that part is wood only, and that the fire box should be made accordingly. As it is important that the shipment should be made during the freighting season, which closes somewhere about the end of March or the middle of April, I should be grateful if you would give this matter early and favorable consideration.

I have the honor to be sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary M.S.C.C.

MB.

Ottawa, February 15th, 1926.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, relative to the request of the Principal of the Lac La Ronge Indian Residential School to be supplied with a belt, switchboard and rotary pump.

In reply I beg to say that we have no funds available to supply this equipment. I would beg to suggest that the same be purchased by the school authorities from their per capita or other receipts.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. T. B. R. Westgate, D.D.,
Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.,
41-43, The Bible House,
Alexander Ave.,
Winnipeg, Man.
The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

In the list of requirements of our Society submitted to your Department for the current year, the following items are mentioned for the school at Lac la Ronge:

1. Fisherman's residence.
2. Cement floor for basement.
3. Bake oven.
4. One quarter mile of fencing.
5. New floor in main building.

Total estimated cost $3,000.00

With regard to the bake oven you have already authorized the transfer of the one now at the Elkhorn School to Lac la Ronge, and I beg to thank you on behalf of our Society for your kind consideration in this matter. The Staff were experiencing much difficulty in the preparation of the school's supply of bread without it, and its installation will be a great relief and comfort to them.

In a letter just received from the Principal he reminds me of the need of the other items mentioned in the list given above and as the transportation of the materials required will not be possible before the end of this year or the beginning of next, unless they are forwarded during the present freighting season which cannot be expected to continue beyond another six or eight weeks at the most, I shall be very grateful if you can let me know if these items have been
sanctioned and the action which will be taken by your Department in providing the same.

If Mr. Inspector Bunn your representative in this City were informed of the amount which might be expended in connection with the above items and authorized to purchase the materials required, they might be delivered at the school before the present freighting season ends.

I commend this suggestion to your favourable consideration and have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

FIELD SECRETARY M.S.C.C.

TBRW/JF.
February 18, 1926.

Memorandum,

Dr. Scott,

There are items totalling $3,000 in the Main Estimates 1926-27, to provide cement floor for the basement and for other comprehensive repairs and improvements at the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. Dr. Westgate in a recent letter pointed out that the improvements cannot be effected during the present year, if the materials are not shipped within the next six or eight weeks.

As I hope to have all accounts for the coming year's activity paid off a year from now, I recommend that Dr. Westgate's request be granted. The materials to be purchased are chiefly cement and lumber and I should be pleased if you would approve of having the purchase placed in Mr. Inspector Bunn's hands. I would suggest limiting the accounts to $1,800.00. The rest of the appropriation will be required for freighting.

Russell J. Terrier

Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, February 20, 1926.

Dear Sir:

MATERIAL FOR LAC LA RONGE.

In reply to your letter of the 20th instant, (132-2-5) requesting a list of the materials required for the Lac la Ronge School, estimate of the cost of the same etc., I beg to submit the following:

1. Enclosed herewith quotations on 4000 feet of edge grain fir flooring from:
   (a) McDiarmid Lumber Co., Prince Albert, $3.4.
   (b) North Star Lumber Co., Prince Albert, $3.4.
   (c) Cushing Bros. Ltd., Saskatoon, $3.2.

This material is required to renew the floors in the rooms and corridors in the main school building where the traffic is the heaviest and the floors installed when the building was erected have become worn out.

In addition to the initial cost of the lumber freight should be added at the rate of $3.00 per 100 lbs. The freighting charges would not exceed $300.00.

2. 1100 lineal feet of quarter round. This is required to finish off the floorings in the rooms and corridors. The cost would be about $2.25 per 100 feet or a total of about $24.75.
The Freighting charges would be covered by the $500.00 mentioned above.

3. 70 Barrels of cement (400 lbs. per bbl.). This is to place in the basement of the main building.

The estimated cost f.o.b. Prince Albert is $6.00 per bbl.

The total weight would be 28000lbs. and the freighting charges at $2.00 per c.w.t. would be approximately $840.00. A summary of the above would be as follows:

1. 4000 ft. flooring (say) $320.00.
   Freight $300.00

2. 1100 ft. quarter round $24.75
   Freight -

3. 70 bbls. cement $420.00
   Freight $840.00

Total $1904.75

I am sending a copy of this letter and of the enclosed quotations to Mr. Inspector Bunn and will be obliged if you will furnish him with your instructions by telegram as per your letter quoted above. The mildness of the weather this winter is causing our Society and Mr. William Bear who has the contract for our freighting from Prince Albert to Lac la Ronge, some anxiety at present.

I have the honour to be, Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary M.S.C.C.

TBRW/JF.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge your letter, number and date as marginally noted above.

This is a confirmation of your telegram of the 2nd March, 1926 re sundry purchases for Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School.

I beg to advise that this telegram was received at 10 a.m. on the 2nd, at 10.10 I communicated with Dr. Westgate by telephone, and read over the message, we arranged for the shipment with the least possible delay. Dr. Westgate wrote to his freight agent at Prince Albert and furnished me with a copy of his letter. I immediately secured any prices that had to be obtained, and I then placed the orders by mail with Messrs Cushing Bros. of Saskatoon for Lumber supplies, and for Canada Portland Cement with the McDiarmid Lumber Co., who are the local agents at Prince Albert, Sask., for the Canada Cement Co. All done on the 2nd instant and mailed.

In placing these orders I have asked for despatch in attention as to shipment.

I have the honor to be,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Sir:

Last Summer the Department made a grant for constructing a proper septic tank for our school. The material for this work came too late to finish the job before the severe weather set in. Also there was not enough cement and I have had to purchase more. I also purchased dynamite for use on excavating hole for septic tank, and for making drain. Our country here is exceedingly rocky, and it is an impossibility to make a hole without the help of explosives.

I was unable to procure competitive prices for this, being so far away from the city.

Your obedient servant,

Chas. J. Hume,
Principal.

Rev. Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of a communication dated the 8th instant from the Assistant Secretary Treasurer of the M.S.C.C., enclosing receipt in duplicate from Duncan Bird, being balance of transportation of electric light repairs from Montreal Lake to Lac la Ronge.

In this connection I enclose herewith copy of a communication to Rev. Canon Gould relative to an account for $122.18, in which was included the cost of the hiring of a team to haul the supplies referred to between the points mentioned. It is thought that the receipts now forwarded cover part of the account for $122.18, and, in order to settle this matter and pay any balance due for freighting, receipts, in duplicate, covering the full amount of the account which was returned to Canon Gould should be attached to vouchers, properly certified by you, in duplicate. In order that this can be done, and proper receipts attached covering the account for the above mentioned amount, the receipts, in duplicate, which have been forwarded are being returned herewith to be attached to the vouchers asked for above.

I shall be pleased if you will give this matter your early attention, in order that payment of any amount due for freighting of supplies to the Lac la Ronge School can be finally settled.

Your obedient servant,

April 1, 1926.

Rev. T.B.R. Westgate, D.D.,
Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.,
Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I enclose herewith freight accounts of cement and lumber which has come to hand in good order. I may say that this part of our freighting has been done in a way specially commendable. The ground from Prince Albert to Lac la Ronge is practically bare of snow, and yet William Bear came through with that great weight on sleighs. Wagons on such a road are entirely out of the question. How, to deliver this freight, which he was forced to do, or have it stored on the way, has taken him sixteen days. Ordinarily, it would take eight or nine days. I am asking, therefore that he be allowed freightage at the rate of $3.50 per 100 lbs. If he is not allowed this rate, he cannot help but lose out in this part of his business. Again, I would like to say that I consider the freighting of this cement and lumber from Prince Albert to Lac la Ronge over roads of which over one hundred miles were practically bare of snow is a feat that few freighters would have attempted. William Bear is a Treaty Indian. He employs other Treaty Indians who live around him to help him in this work. Not that he makes very much out of it himself, but it gives those men work during the winter. I do sincerely hope, therefore, that you will recommend that he be allowed the rate of $3.50 per 100 lbs.

Yours faithfully,

(sgd) Chas. F. Hives.
Principal.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to my letter of Feb. 24th and your reply on Mar. 1st (132-215) relative to the purchase of lumber and cement for our Society's school at Lac la Ronge, I now beg to enclose herewith freight bills from Mr. W. A. Bear aggregating $1070.65 and will be obliged if you will forward the same to him to the Imperial Bank, Prince Albert, Sask., and ask them to credit his account. Along with the bills I enclosed in duplicate a certified statement from the Principal. I should state for your information that the usual freighting charge made by Mr. Bear under contract with our Society is $3.00 per hundred pounds. From the enclosed covering letter received from the Principal you will note that he recommends, owing to the great difficulty experienced and the unusually great length of time required to bring this freight through to the school, owing to the break up of the roads, he recommends that the rate on this freight should be $3.50 per hundred, and this recommendation has my full support. For a time it looked as if these could not be taken through at all, and it is only through the special effort on the part of the freighter and with increased expenditure to himself that it was landed at the school and in good condition.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Field Secretary M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to your letter of March 1st, 1926, (132-2-5) and other correspondence on the same file relative to the requirements of our Society's School at Lac la Ronge this year, I should like to know if your Department can furnish any assistance in installing the cement floor in the basement of this institution. In a letter just received from the Principal he states that gravel and sand have to be brought from different parts of the lake by canoe, and estimates that the cost will approximate $800.00 over and above the labour which the school management will have to undertake.

As this sum cannot be met from our Society's funds I should like to know if your Department can render assistance in this connection. Should you be unable to do so I fear the installation of the cement floor may have to be postponed. If part of the total required could be met this year the remainder might be undertaken in 1927.

I remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Rev. T. B. R. Westgate, D.D.,
Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.,
Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I beg to place before you for your consideration certain conditions in the girls' section of our School, relative to toilet conveniences. At present we have two water closets inside for the girls. One for each of the dormitories. There are over sixty girls. There are no water closets on the ground floor, and unless those upstairs are used for daytime, which you may understand is a great inconvenience, the outside toilets have to be used, which I consider are not only a nuisance, but also a great danger, especially during the winter months. You may very well see that it is impossible to allow over sixty girls running up and down stairs at all times during the day, at the same time the danger from an outside toilet is very great during the extreme cold weather of our winters.

I would therefore urgently recommend that two inside combination water closets be installed on the ground floor. We have the space for this conveniently near the girls' recreation room, and closeted so as to be private and not offensive.

We can do the work ourselves if we have the following material.

- 2 combination water closet sets complete to floor.
- 2 lead bends.
- 60 ft. 4" soil pipe.
- 50 lbs. pig lead.
- 25 " oakum.
- 80 ft. 3" gal. iron pipe, in ten ft. lengths, and couplings for same.
- 2 union couplings 3"
- 3 soil pipe tees 4"
- 2 45 degree soil pipe bends.
- 1 doz. 3" gal. iron elbows.
- 1 " 3" " 45 degree
- 1 " 3" " tees.
- 2 only 3" waste cocks.
- 1 doz. bushings assorted ½" to 1¼"

I most sincerely trust that this may be granted, as I do consider that the outside toilet is a great menace to the health of our girls.
If this receives favourable consideration, would you kindly order the above and instruct shipping in the usual way, at the same time notifying Wm. Bear, who will see it through.

Yours faithfully,

(sgd) Chas. F. Hives.

Principal.
The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith a copy of a letter received from the Principal of our Society's School at Lac la Ronge in which he points out the need of two inside combination water closets for this institution. As the School management will undertake the installation if your Department will supply the material required, I trust that an authorization to purchase and forward the material may be granted.

I commend this matter to your sympathetic consideration, and remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6316, file 656-5, part 4)
The Church authorities request that the Department allow a grant for labour in connection with the placing of a cement floor in the basement of the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. There is an item in our Estimates for the current year for the purpose. However, no funds were specifically provided in the Governor General's warrant. If you wish to authorize the activity, funds could be found in the general item "Buildings under Contract, etc." You will remember that there is provided $96,750 for last year's building contracts and obligations.

Dr. Westgate states that the labour costs will approximate $800, as gravel and sand will have to be brought from different parts of the lake by canoe. The correspondence shows that, if we don't allow the grant, the installation of the cement floor will have to be postponed. I believe the cement is already at the school.

Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, July 28, 1926.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, concerning the labour costs of the cement floor in the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. I note that gravel and sand can be brought with difficulty from different parts of the lake. I believe this activity should be proceeded with, and any hauling costs which cannot be handled by the school management will receive favourable consideration by the Department. It must be understood, however, that the expenses should be kept as low as possible.

I have also your letter of the 15th instant, requesting two water closets to be installed on the ground floor. You may purchase, after securing competitive prices, the equipment listed in the principal's letter of the 14th of May and arrange for shipment to the school. I note that the work can be done by the staff.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Boarding School,
Lac la Ronge, Sask.
Aug. 14, 1926.

Sir:

I enclose herewith returns of work done on septic tank at our school. The Department kindly made a grant of $200.00 for this work. I am sorry to say that it has been quite impossible to keep within this amount. Although I have tried to be as careful as possible and have done much of the work myself and staff. Owing to the rocky nature of this land through which we had to carry the overflow, the work was exceedingly slow and difficult, and therefore more labour was engaged than would have been had the land been less difficult to dig.

I may say that an excellent job has been done, and that we now have a disposal system that will do the work, and which complies with the law.

The men were all paid by order on the Hudson's Bay and the Revillon Freres trading posts.

I beg to say again that I am sorry we were not able to keep within the limits of the two hundred dollars but I am very thankful of the results of our work, and hope that the Department will be able to meet the extra expense entailed.

Your obedient servant,

Chas. F. Hines.
Principal.

Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Regina, Sask., August 27th, 1926.

Sir:

I am submitting my report on the annuity payments throughout Treaty No. 10, for 1926.

JAMES ROBERT'S BAND AT LAC LA RONGE

I arrived at this place on the evening of Saturday the 26th of June. We spent Sunday at the boarding school. We thus had an opportunity of observing the children and how they were kept. I found everything very satisfactory. Children were well fed and were happy. The school was closed for holidays, so I did not do any class room inspection. The disposal system of refuse had been completed and was a great success, or I should say, is, a great success.

W. R. Taylor,
Indian Agent.
REPORT OF DR. H. C. GEORGE
TREATY TRIP NO.10, 1926.

There is great need of an infirmary in connection with the LaRonge Mission school, as at present there is no opportunity of isolating sick children from the well. This revealed itself very plainly during the last couple of years during which time, three children died, in the school, of Tuberculous Meningitis - members of the staff giving up their individual rooms for the treatment of these cases.

H. C. George.

[Handwritten note:]
Write direct to Principal for statement as to space available for sick.
Ottawa, September 27, 1926.

Rev. Sir:

Dr. George, who accompanied the party on the annuity payments throughout Treaty No. 10 this past summer, in a report on his visit to the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School, draws attention to the need of more accommodation for the isolating and care of sick children.

In this connection I shall be pleased if you will inform the Department as to what space is available as an infirmary for any pupils who may be ill at the school, also what arrangements, if any, you would advise be made in order to provide the necessary accommodation for the proper isolating and treatment of sick pupils.

Your obedient servant,

We here try to do our best, but we have no medical diplomas. We run up against illnesses that are baffling to us. We are in the ordinary way seven days away from the nearest medical doctor. We just grope in the dark, and often have to sit down and watch the poor little sufferer die. I speak from experience.

What we need is a good strong man or woman; not necessarily a brilliant doctor, but practical and with little fear of discouragements, and with a small hospital to isolate cases.

We have a saw mill where we can manufacture lumber for building. We have the stone for foundations and the lime stone for plaster. A small hospital could be built for a reasonable sum of money, at a convenient and safe distance from the school, and still receive its light and water from the school supply.

A doctor could board and if necessary room at the school, and I feel sure that such a scheme would prove its worth.

At present we are isolating cases in the kindergarten classroom, and overcrowding the junior classroom. It is the only arrangement that can be made, and in any case we would have to build in order to have an infirmary.

I beg to say sir, that the suggestion of a hospital and doctor is the only recommendation that I would consider worthwhile, and also urgently beg that the same may receive due consideration.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal.

Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
would undoubtedly have succumbed to that sickness had we left them. I mean that the Whooping cough had developed into Pneumonia, a disease that these people are incapable of fighting when the bed is just a blanket on the cold damp ground. All of these children are now doing well and regaining their former health.

If these people are worth saving, and I think there can be no doubt on that matter, then my first and I really believe the only worthwhile suggestion and recommendation is a small hospital with a qualified doctor, either man or woman in charge of it.

The same could have our Jas. Roberts band, William Charles band, Amos Charles and Peter Ballendine bands under his care. Lac la Ronge is central to these bands mentioned. The Jas. Roberts band, Amos Charles and Peter Ballendine bands are fairly healthy Indians. If a medical man were placed in charge of them now, before Syphilis etc. work havoc amongst them, they may not only preserve the race, but also be the means of saving them from the suffering ultimately from the scourges of these terrible diseases.

Of one thing I am confident: A medical doctor will in the near future have to reside here, and maybe more than one. Not only for the sake of the health of these Indians, but also as a safeguard to the white population. Why wait for that time?

We have over one hundred pupils in school at the present time. I am safe in saying that eighty five percent have never been vaccinated. Times I have written about this matter, and promise has been made that the Treaty doctor will be given instruction to vaccinate during his visit. He has never yet brought vaccine with him. Moreover he informs me that it is hardly fair to the children he vaccinates or to the doctor to vaccinate so many at one time, and not be able to stay and attend in case of complications.

Smallpox is bound to, sooner or later, find its way into our midst, and then woe betide us. It is fifteen years since Whooping cough last visited these people until this year, and then it found fifteen years of progeny awaiting its arrival. Is it to be the same with Smallpox or Diphtheria?
Lac la Ronge, Sask.
Oct. 16, 1926.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your communication of the 27th ultimo, letter No. 132-2-5, I beg ye say that it will afford me a great deal of pleasure to respond to your inquiry of a matter so important.

While Doctor George of Treaty party No IO was here he expressed himself as being shocked at the poor accommodation we have for a school of our size, and especially in face of the fact that we are so far away from medical help, and hospital facilities such as they have nearer civilisation. May I therefore be permitted to emphasize this point of our need of a hospital and attendant. Not only for the sake of our own pupils, but also for the sake of the whole band of Jas. Roberts, and the adjoining bands of Amos Charles, Peter Ballendine, and William Charles.

As no doubt you are aware sir, the Jas. Roberts band have heretofore been one of the healthiest bands of Indians, and a glance over the statistics of the past ten years will show a substantial increase in the population. Six years ago they had a setback when the Spanish Influenza invaded us, and it took some years to regain their normal health and vigor. I was through that time with these people, and known not only how they suffered, but also how great was the value of expert and practical help at such a time.

This year we have had a repetition of a somewhat similar nature. During the months of July and August of this year there were eleven death resulting from Whooping cough. At least ten out of the eleven deaths were direct resultant of whooping cough. Had these people been able to receive proper care, I have no doubt that most of them would be with us still. I carried three little children into our school, Children who had been given up by their parents as too far gone, and who

Dear Sir:-

I am much obliged to you for your letter of the 6th inst (132-2-5) and regret that through an oversight I was not informed that your Department had paid the sum of $128.18 for repairs to the electric lighting plant at the Lac la Ronge School before I submitted my request. Dear Sir:

In a letter just received from the Principal of our Society's School at Lac la Ronge, and dated November 9th, he directs my attention to the very urgent need of fully modern laundry equipment for this school, and expresses the hope that it may be purchased in time to reach the school during the present freighting season. His letter reads, in part, as follows:

"At the present time we have a little family power washer, worked by a one and a half power gasoline engine. This is a very small affair, and certainly not able to do the work required. Hence we have to resort to hand washers and the old-fashioned scrub board. This would not be so bad had we the big girls, but you will notice by the roll, that the great majority of our pupils are under the age of twelve years. This is a very urgent request........."

On page 4 of the list of requirements forwarded by our Society to be provided by your Department next year, you will see that under this school modern laundry equipment has been included at an estimated cost of $1,500.00. As there can be no question whatever as to the necessity of this item of equipment in so large a school, I beg to request that provision of the same be given favourable consideration, and supplied as suggested by the Principal, in time to reach the school before the close of the present freighting season.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.O.C.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith account of charges on freighting of material in connection with our church building, and for which purpose a grant was kindly promised by the Department.

Part of this freight was brought in during the Summer by William Bear. The account of this freighting was forwarded to you, and I presume paid for.

We are very grateful for the help received from the Department, and I assure you that it has all been used to the best advantage.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I have to inform you that we are having trouble without pump and engine. The trouble seems to be general. That is there are parts of the pump badly worn, and the cylinder of the engine is cracked, and lets in the water, so that there is great difficulty in starting it, and in keeping it going. It should by rights be sent out to be properly repaired by welding. This we cannot do, as it would leave us without any means of getting our water supply.

The only thing to be done is to ask the Department of Indian Affairs for a replica of the outfit that we have at present. Then send the old one out to be properly repaired, and returned to be on hand in case of trouble.

The present one is a Fairbanks-Morse 3 H.P. engine and Typhoon pump, with two inch discharge.

I hope this matter will be attended to as soon as possible.

Yours faithfully,

(sgd) C. F. Hives,
Principal.

Ottawa, March 12, 1927.

Rev. Sir:

I have your telegram of the 11th instant, relative to laundry equipment for the Lac La Ronge Indian Residential School.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange for the purchase, after obtaining competitive prices, of 2 hand washing machines for this school. Please forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred.

The Department will be unable to purchase and forward the heavy laundry equipment for this school before the freighting season ends, but hopes to be able to purchase and have same forwarded early next winter.

I have also your letter of the 9th instant, with reference to the water pump and engine at this school. I am today writing to Mr. Inspector Bunn, of Winnipeg, authorizing him to purchase the equipment mentioned by the Reverend Principal. You might telephone to him and explain the advisability of immediate shipment.

I believe that the Reverend Principal would be well advised to have the old pump and engine repaired. The geographical situation of this school is such that it would be wise to have a second unit available in event of trouble in the future.

Rev. T. B. R. Westgate, D.D.,

Sir:

I have the honour to refer to a letter written by Dr. Westgate to the Department dated 16th July last and your reply thereto No. 132-2-5 dated the 28th of July.

Dr. Westgate's letter requests that the sum of £200.00 might be apportioned for the work in connection with the cement floor at the Indian Residential School at Lac la Ronge.

The amount so far contributed by the Department is £562.50 of which £252.50 was paid to the Hudson's Bay Company and £310.00 to Messrs Revillon Freres. I now beg to enclose Return of Labour in duplicate duly certified for £150.00 in favour of A.C. Hastings which has been paid by the Commission.

I am instructed to request that a cheque may issue in due course.

I have the honour to be

Sir

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Asst. Secy.Treas.

You will please find enclosed herewith a cheque amounting to $46.20 and a copy of a letter from the Canada Cement Company of the 16th instant, in explanation of the same.

This Company promised to make an allowance for returned sacks used in a consignment of 280 sacks of cement (70 barrels) to our Lac la Ronge School for the basement floor. Many of the sacks were damaged and for this reason the amount refunded is not larger than that specified.

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

During my recent visit to our Society's School at Lac la Ronge the Principal directed my attention to the following urgent needs in the way of improvements and equipment, and having presented the same to our Commission at a meeting on the 14th instant, I was instructed to submit the same to you for your consideration. The requirements are as follows:

1. Paint
   - 60 gallons grey paint.
   - 10 " green for trimmings.
   - 5 " white for window sashes.

2. For inside decorating. 720 lbs. galsmine in the following quantities:
   - 2 doz. packages buff (5 lb. packages)
   - 2 " white
   - 2 " rose pink
   - 2 " azure
   - 2 " ivory
   - 2 " grey

In connection with the above the following is also required:
   - 5 gallons Spar varnish
   - 10 " paint oil
   - 3 " turpentine
   - 2 doz suitable brushes

The school management gave me to understand that they would
undertake the work if the materials were supplied not later than the end of July or early in August.

In addition to the above 3 complete sets of wood burning furnace grates are required for the furnaces installed in the basement. The furnaces are McClary #419 Famous Magnet. For estimate of cost see statement below.

A complete cobbler's outfit for repairing boots. For estimate of cost see statement below.

A welding outfit. For estimate of cost see statement below.

Fare box for the bake oven, capacity 100 loaves. For estimate of cost see statement below.

Hot water heating tank, treble the size of the one installed which holds 90 gallons. For estimate of cost see statement below.

With regard to the cost of the above items I have secured the following estimate from firms who could supply the same:

1. Paint, kalsomine, etc. Winnipeg Paint and Glass Co., f.o.b. Prince Albert $129.00.

2. Sherwin Williams Co., f.o.b. Winnipeg, $123.00. In addition to this cost of freight on approximately 1100 lbs. would have to be reckoned at summer freight rates of 7¢ a lb. or $77.00. The total amount asked under this heading in our list of requirements presented to your Department to be supplied this year was $300.00.

3. The estimated cost of the 3 sets of furnace grates as given by the McClary Mfg. Co., is approximately $15.00 a set f.o.b. Prince Albert or $45.00 for the 3 sets. To this must be added freighting charges from Prince Albert to the School. The 3 sets weigh approximately 204 lbs. and this at 7¢ a lb. would be $14.28.

4. The T. Eaton Co., of Winnipeg have estimated the cost of the cobbler's outfit at $10.15. This estimate includes cement, awls, hemp, bristles, ink, rivets, tacks, etc., but omits hammers, nails, and certain other essential items. I am unable to give the weight or an estimate of the freighting charges but this would not be more than say $3.00. The estimates should be increased to $12.00 for the items omitted plus $3.00 for freight.

5. Estimated cost of a suitable welding outfit f.o.b. Winnipeg as given by the Hudson's Bay Co., is $72.00. An additional $10.00 would be sufficient for freight.
Cast iron fire box with cast iron collar $14.00 f.o.b. Prince Albert. The bake oven for which this is required was in use for some time at the Elkhorn School but transferred to Lac la Ronge when Elkhorn was supplied with a new bake oven. It had originally a black iron fire box with cast iron collar which cost only one-third of the cast iron fire box which is now supplied by the J. J. Daoust Ltd., St. Boniface, Man. The weight of this is not given but the freight may be estimated at about $3.00.

6. Hot water heating tank. The Hudson's Bay Co., Winnipeg quote one tank with a capacity of 192 gallons at $125.00 f.o.b. Prince Albert. To this would be added the sum of approximately $25.00 for a range water jacket, pipe connections, couplings, elbows, etc. The weight of this is not available but being a bulky item the freight will probably approximate $50.00.

As all of the above items are urgently required and should be supplied at the earliest possible date, I shall be obliged if you will undertake to provide the same or authorize our Society or Mr. Inspector Bunn of Winnipeg to do so.

With regard to the other requirements which our Society requested your Department to supply this year to the Lac la Ronge School, I shall be very glad to know what sum is available. The estimated total amount required was given in our list as $4,000. As all of the above mentioned items can be provided for a sum not exceeding $600.00 a very considerable balance should be available for other improvements and items of equipment.

A new class-room approximately 22' x 50' would be of immense service to the school as it could also be used for meetings, entertainments, gymnasium purposes, etc., if provided with a full size basement. The cost of this apart from the furnace, door and window frames, glass, shingles, locks, hinges, nails, etc., would not exceed the sum of $2,500. This is one of the two other urgent major requirements of this school. The other is fully modern laundry equipment and which the Commission trust that, if provision has not been made for the same requested in our list forwarded to the Deputy Mupt. General through our General Secretary towards the close of last year, to provide the laundry equipment during the current fiscal year, necessary steps may be taken for provision of the same during the next fiscal year.

I have the honour to be, Sir,
Yours obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

TBRW/JF

Ottawa, July 4, 1927.

Reverend Sir:

I wish to refer to your letter of the 20th ultimo, relative to the requirements of the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. You are authorized to purchase the paint and kalsomine, varnish, etc., mentioned in your letter, at an estimated cost of $139. I note that the Sherwin Williams Company, of Winnipeg, have quoted the lowest price. You may also purchase three sets of furnace grates at an estimated cost of $45, a cobbler's outfit at a cost of $10.13, a welding outfit at a cost of $72, a cast iron firebox with cast iron collar at a price of $14 and a hot water heating tank at an estimated cost of $125. You should get competitive prices for any of the more expensive materials. I understand that freight costs will be added to the above estimates.

The other requirements will receive consideration when presented to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Re: Paint etc., for the Lac la Ronge school

Dear Sir,

With further reference to my letter of June 20 and your reply of July 4 (No. 132-2-5) relative to the paint, kalsomine, varnish etc., for our Society's School at Lac la Ronge I regret to state that through an oversight in copying out the list of requirements as set forth in my letter of June 20 referred to above the quantities of paint required were not included in the estimates given on page 2 of that letter. The paints required are as follows:

60 gallons of grey.
10 " green.
5 " white.

I have asked The Winnipeg Paint & Glass Company to submit a tender for the same and they quote the sum of $321.40 f.o.b. Prince Albert. The Sherwin Williams Company of Winnipeg will supply the same f.o.b. Prince Albert for $279. As this paint is really urgently needed an order has been placed for the same with The Sherwin Williams Company so that it may be forwarded in the same shipment with the other items mentioned in your letter of July 4. I deeply regret that the cost of this paint was not included in the estimates furnished in my letter of June 20th and trust that under the circumstances and in view of the necessity of having the whole shipment go forward as a unit you may approve the action I have taken and sanction the purchase of this paint.

Believe me Sir,

Yours very truly,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Rev. T.B.R.Westgate, D.D.,

Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

On July 24th and the two or three days following we had quite a narrow escape from being wiped out by a bush fire, caused by lightning which struck about three miles west of the school.

The day following there came a very hot dry wind which drove the fire toward the school. I have always considered ourselves fairly well protected from bush fires. You will no doubt remember the long stretch of muskeg at the back of the school. You did not go over this place as I considered it too wet, although our fuel for next winter was over there. Well, the wind swept the fire across the muskeg at a terrific rate right straight for the school buildings. The building nearest the fire was the gasoline and coal oil house. But we were ahead of it there, as we had all the barrels rolled down to the lake when we saw the danger approaching. We were also very well prepared with hose over all the important buildings, and saturated the roofs with water. At times the smoke was so dense around the buildings, the school could not be seen from the lake shore just in front, where the ladies were waiting with their suit cases. It was a very anxious time for awhile, and I shed many tears on account of the smoke, but, thank God the buildings were kept safe.

All that night and the two days following we were on duty putting out fires, and even now as I write, it is still burning in the muskeg. The wind has changed, , the fire is going West.

I am sorry to say that a great deal of our wood supply has been burnt up, and especially the beautiful big pile of short wood, which the boys and Buster Brown took such pride in cutting. It was all destroyed.

I am enclosing an account for orders paid out to fire fighters. I am sorry to say also that I shall have to ask for another $175.00 to replace the wood we had burnt. I may say that we did our best to save this wood,
but it was utterly impossible.

For miles to the West of us, it is a black waste.

Yours faithfully,

"Chas.F.Hives"

Principal.
Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing for your information copy of a letter just received from the Rev. C.F.Hives, principal of our Society School at Lac la Ronge.

You will note from this letter that this School had an extremely narrow escape from complete destruction by a bush fire which was caused by lightning, and we can all, I feel certain, join with the principal in thanking God that the buildings were kept safe. It seems to me that he and his staff, and the helpers he engaged to protect the building and adjoining property, are deserving of the highest commendation, and I feel certain that a short message from you to this effect, addressed to the Principal direct, would be very pleasing and encouraging to him and his staff.

You will note from his letter that he enclosed an account, amounting to $88.50, made up of Orders given to the different Indians who helped in protecting the School property, and I am enclosing this account in duplicate in the hope that your Department may be able to meet this unexpected expenditure out of your contingency fund.

You will note also from the latter part of his letter that a great deal of the School's wood supply has been burned up, and especially the short wood which was ready for the kitchen range, and that he is asking our Society for a special grant of $175.00 to meet this loss.

After the generous assistance which you have already given our Society towards meeting the necessary repairs and improvements at this School this year, I am reluctant to ask you to come to our Society's assistance in meeting this request, but it has come so unexpectedly, and at a time when
August 25th, 1927.

The Secretary, Dept. Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

I am at a complete loss to know how this amount is to be found, that I am obliged to ask you if you can come to our assistance in this connection by providing a part at least, if not the whole, of this amount.

We have a similar request from the Hay River School, where a bush fire has also destroyed practically $200.00 worth of wood, which was cut ready for next year.

During my approaching visit to your Department, I contemplated taking up the question of a special grant to meet the loss sustained at Hay River, but the need is so urgent at Lac la Ronge that I felt it my duty to lay the situation before you without any further delay.

Trusting you may be able to meet the enclosed bill, and to furnish the help requested with regard to replacing the wood which was burnt, I remain,

Sir,

Your Obedient Servant,

[Signature]

FIELD SECRETARY M.S.C.C.

TBRW/K

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 28th. The list price of the
160 ampere, 32 cells battery cells is $262.50. We have always
given the regular dealers discount to Rev. C.F. Hives, and therefore,
it would cost you $196.50 f.o.b. Saskatoon plus transportation
to Prince Albert which would be $6.90 making a total of $203.40.

The old batteries are only worth 2½¢ per pound for the lead
that is in them this amounts to about $12.00 per set. It would
cost more than that amount to bring them in to Saskatoon so we
cannot make any allowance on these old batteries.

The three Kilowatt plant with the crank case broken and the
field torn out. It would cost more to repair this than what you
could sell it for secondhand and this would make the plant useless
to us for which we are very sorry.

The reason the life of the batteries is so short is because
they have a very heavy lot to carry and they get a very heavy charge
and discharge and this shortens the life of any battery.

We trust that this is a satisfactory explanation and thanking
you in anticipation of your order for a new set, we remain,

Yours very truly,

LEMERY-DENISON ELECTRIC LTD.

OLL/CML
The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

On September the 12th last the Rev. C.F. Hives, Principal of our Society's school at Lac la Ronge wrote to me as follows with regard to the light plant at this school:

"I beg to place before you our need of a new set of batteries for our Light plant. Some of these have been on the go now for nearly three years. Others for over four years, and all are getting into bad state. Unless they are removed, we may have difficulties during the coming winter. We require thirty-two cells, Exide type, and have heretofore received these from the Lemery-Denison Electric Company, Saskatoon.

I would suggest that they be asked to take back the present batteries as part payment. Also we still have the Delco Light plant here. The dynamo and engine are in good repair. The crank case needs renewing and we have had to rob it of a few small parts in order to install the present light plant. It would, nevertheless, be worth something, and would bring down the cost of the new batteries, if the Lemery-Denison people would take it as part payment."

As soon as I received the above letter I wrote to the Lemery-Denison people in Saskatoon and enclose herewith for your information a copy of their reply.

When I visited the Lac la Ronge school last May the Principal informed me at that time that he felt certain the batteries would have to be renewed in the near future. I asked him to watch them carefully for the next few months and then to
furnish me with a specific recommendation in this connection. As he has recommended that thirty-two new battery cells of the Exide type be provided I shall be obliged if you will either undertake to have these purchased from the Lemery-Denison Ltd., Saskatoon at a total cost of $203.40 f.o.b. Prince Albert or authorise me to make the purchase and forward the bill to you for payment at a later date. The battery cells cannot now be forwarded to the school until the winter trail opens which will be some time in the month of December.

Believe me Sir,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.
Ottawa, October 10, 1927.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, informing the Department that new batteries are required for the lighting plant at the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School, and stating the cost of same.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange for the purchase and forwarding to the school of 32 new battery cells of the Exide type. We note that these can be purchased from Lemery-Denison, Ltd., Saskatoon, at a cost of $203.40, F.O.B. Prince Albert. Please obtain an account, in duplicate, which you should certify in the usual manner and forward to the Department for payment.

It is noted from the copy of the letter which you forwarded from the above firm that it would cost more than the old batteries are worth to have them returned to Saskatoon, and this firm is not, therefore, prepared to make any allowance for the old batteries.

You should inform the Principal of the School that he is to see that no electrical attachments, such as toasters, washing machines, etc., are used in connection with the lighting plant, as, by doing so, the batteries would soon become exhausted.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Dear Sir:

Re: Laundry equipment for Lac la Ronge school

With further reference to my telegram of March 11th last and your reply to the same on March 12th (No. 132-2-5) relative to the purchase of laundry equipment for our Society's school at Lac la Ronge I beg to state that in a letter just received from the Principal he informs me that the need for modern laundry equipment for this institution has become quite acute and he greatly hopes that this equipment may be purchased and forwarded to Prince Albert in time to be conveyed to the school immediately after the winter trail opens. So far as we are able to tell at present this will be early in December.

If this laundry equipment is to be purchased and forwarded at the time suggested above I shall be obliged if you will notify me to this effect as the Principal states that he would like to build an engine house attached to the laundry before the severely cold weather sets in and I am anxious to give him as much notice as possible. He states that the building of the engine house can be accomplished without any expense to your Department beyond the cement for the floor. The amount which will be required for this purpose he estimates to be 12 sacks and I should like to have an authorization to purchase and forward the same and submit the bills to you for payment.

Thanking you in advance for a prompt reply to this letter, I have the honour to be Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Field Secretary M.S.C.C.
Ottawa, October 11, 1927.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to laundry equipment for the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. It is true that there was an appropriation for laundry machinery at this institution, amounting to $1500, but I have to inform you that this amount has already been exceeded in connection with the following items: Engine and pump, washing machines, sawmill, belt, paint, etc., hot water tank, other mechanical plant and freight. I regret, therefore, that the Department cannot give favourable consideration to the shipment of laundry machinery this early winter.

I should be grateful, however, if you would let me know just what machinery is required and how it is proposed to run it. This information is necessary for our file so that, when funds are available, early shipment can be made.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. T. B. R. Westgate, D. D.,
Field Secretary, M. S. C. C.,

"The question of supplying an Infirmary at the
Lac La Ronge School is one that I do not think should be
overlooked, and no doubt the matter of a small hospital
at Lac la Ronge will also receive consideration."

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF DR. G.F. ALYOT,
Medical Officer with Indian Treaty
Party No. 10, 1927. Original on
File 3-132.

"With regard to the Mission School at Lac la
Ronge, I strongly recommend the construction, or alteration
of the present building in such a way that sufficient room
be made for both a boys' and girls' sick room or infirmary.
This to be done whether it is decided to build a hospital
at the present time or not. The present dormitories are
overcrowded, and some children have to sleep two in a single
bed. Besides the two T.B. cases sent out for hospital treat-
ment who were in the stage when they ran the greatest chance
of infecting others, were living day and night one in the
boys' and one in the girls' over-crowded dormitory. Also a
pneumonia case and two others with flu, all in the common
dormitory. This is a very unsanitary and bad state of
affairs in any school, particularly among Indians who are so
susceptible to Tuberculosis.

"It was necessary to keep these sick children in the
dormitories I understand because there is no infirmary pro-
vided for children who are ill. Again I strongly recommend
that something be done immediately to offset this unhealthy
condition."
Ottawa, Nov. 24, 1925.

Ottawa, November 30, 1927.

Reverend Sir:

I wish to refer to my letter of this file of the 11th ultimo, relative to laundry machinery for the Lac La Ronge Indian Residential School. It has been decided to supply some of the laundry equipment required without delay. If the Principal's plan to erect an engine house to be attached to the laundry can now be proceeded with, you may arrange for the purchase of 12 sacks of cement and see that it is shipped to Lac la Ronge.

If necessary, please make enquiries without delay concerning what machinery is most urgently needed. When we have your recommendation to hand, further consideration will be given.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

WE are not philanthropists, but the proposition which we have been presenting to you—to install a Unit which will enable you to do your own laundry work, instead of having it done outside—is almost philanthropic, inasmuch as it gives you the opportunity to install a modern plant, fitted to your needs, and pay for it out of the savings which you effect.

That this is feasible is not a question any longer—it has been done, and is being done, by many small institutions, summer resort hotels and clubs all over the country.

Tell us what your laundry bills amount to so far this year, and we will tell you whether it would be wise for you to install a Unit.

If we cannot prove it will save you money, we will frankly say so—we will not run the risk of having a dissatisfied customer on our list. We aim to sell only where a Unit is really needed; the profit on any one sale is not so great as to tempt us to load you up with any machinery you cannot use to the best advantage.

If a summer club can pay for its entire laundry equipment in one short season out of its own and its guests laundry work, then it would seem that every institution should be able and anxious to install one of our five Units and make it a source of real profit.

In case you have mislaid the folders which we sent you giving full information on the five Units, we will gladly send you others showing the adaptability and cost of each Unit. One of the Units, No. 3, is illustrated on the back of this sheet. There are four others, and if you will give us an idea of how much work you have done each week, we will indicate which of the five will be best for your use.

The money which you have been paying for your work outside, added to the extra work you can do, will pay for the machinery you need. Let us reason this matter out with you in our mutual interest. We will welcome your communications, and will be honest in our opinions and suggestions.

It is Now Up To You—
Write Today

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo, and to state in reply as follows:

1. I have placed an order with the Manville Hardware Co., Prince Albert, for 12 sacks of cement for the Lac la Ronge School, and will, in due course, furnish you with a statement of their account. The building of the frame part of the engine house can be effected during the winter months, but it may not be possible to utilize the cement before spring. This, however, can only be freighted through in the winter, and this will explain why an order has been placed for immediate shipment.

2. With regard to the laundry equipment required for this School, I may say that I have asked the Principal for a specific recommendation in this connection. As some weeks must elapse before this can be received, I am wondering if the fact that the School has a capacity, and an enrolment of 100 pupils, should not furnish sufficient information to decide the kind of equipment required. The items will include -

(a) Cylindrical washer.
(b) Extractor.
(c) Drying tumbler, and
(d) Flat-work ironer.

Three of the above are illustrated on the enclosed advertising circular from the Beaver Laundry Machinery Co., and further particulars could be received from them.

Beyond this suggestion I am not in a position to offer
you any further information until I receive the Principal's recommendation, except to state that the operating power will be a gasoline engine.

Thanking you for your kind consideration of the needs of this School, I remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

TBRW/JF

Enc.
MEMORANDUM:

Funds are available for the purchase of laundry machinery for the Lac La Ronge Indian Residential School. This requirement has been urged upon the Department for two years. Last summer when I was about to bring the matter to your attention I remembered that it was difficult to ship heavy equipment except after freeze-up. A cylindrical washer and an extractor are, I believe, most needed, and these will cost approximately $1,100 F.O.B. Toronto. I should be pleased to have your authority to arrange the purchase.

Supt. of Indian Education.

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

In a letter just received from the Principal of our Lac la Ronge School, and dated Nov. 26th, he gives a list of various items of furnishings and equipment which are required urgently, and I am writing to solicit your cooperation in providing the same. His letter reads, in part, as follows:

"We also require a bed-room suite for one of the staff rooms. We have never had sufficient, and now that we have to accommodate the Nurse, we really require a bed, dresser, bed-room table and chair."

His letter does not give an estimate of the cost of these items, but they are listed (walnut finish) in Eaton's Catalogue at the following prices:

| Item          | Price |
|---------------|-------|
| Single bed    | $22.50|
| Dresser       | $2.50 |
| Bed-room table| $2.00 |
| Bed-room chair| $1.50 |

The buffet would cost approximately $20, while the larger window blinds would cost $1.25 each, and the smaller ones $1.15 each, making the total cost of the blinds $49.00.

A bed-room suite and buffet of inferior quality could, of course, be purchased at a lower price, but I am unable to recommend the freighting to so remote a centre, of any furniture of less value than that which I have quoted.

The prices given are f.o.b. Winnipeg. The total cost
of freight from here to Prince Albert would not exceed $5.00. The freight from Prince Albert to Lac la Ronge at the rate of 3¢ a lb. would not exceed $20., making a grand total of approximately $187.00, for these furnishings delivered at Lac la Ronge.

As it is important that they should reach the School during the present freighting season, I shall be obliged if you will kindly let me know what assistance your Department will be prepared to render in providing the same.

I have the honour to be, Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

TBRW/JF

The Basket is of Perforated Copper, heavily tinned and strongly reinforced by steel bands. The Oversize Steel Spindle operates on a hardened ball point and button running in a long bronze bearing. The bearing is supported by two large rubber springs, so arranged and designed as to make this Machine self-balancing. A large amount of working space has been provided round the bearing, making very easy and quick adjustment or changing of the rubber springs.

The Beaver circulating oil system ensures complete lubrication of the main bearing at all times. The oil well is very accessible for inspection of the oil level and refilling. From the oil well the oil is led to a sump in the base of the machine, whence it circulates through the bearing, returning to the sump. Owing to the large capacity of the oil well only occasional attention is required.

All Beaver Extractors have countershafts attached to the curb, and may be for straight or angle drive. The angle drive, as shown in the cut, costs a little more than the straight drive, but effects a saving in floor space, and allows the Extractor to be placed in line with the washers. All Extractors have our improved adjustable friction clutch pulley, which gives a gradual increase in speed without strain to any part of the Machine. Motor drive extractors are direct connected with push button control.

A Galvanized wire safety cover is fitted and so arranged that the cover must be closed before the Machine can be started.

Beaver Roller Bearing Washer

Header on End

This is a very strongly constructed washer, built for heavy duty. The material throughout is of the best grade and no pains have been spared to produce a machine that can be relied upon to give many years of satisfactory service.

The Main Trunion Journals operate in roller bearings. Less power is required to drive the machine and wear is almost entirely eliminated, with the result that all gears are always in correct mesh and alignment. Broken gears, worn trunion journals and bearing replacements are never necessary on this washer. The main bearings are entirely separated from the tub by packed stuffing boxes, which absolutely prevents oil and grease from entering the washer or water from coming out.

The Reversing Movement is our Beaver Ball Bearing type in which all the thrust of operating the belt shifter slides is taken by hardened steel balls. The movement is designed so as to give a positive even shifting of the belts, irrespective of wear, so that the cylinder...
Beaver Roller Bearing Washer—Header on End

runs the same number of revolutions in either direction. The gears are machine cut from solid blanks and the main gear is thirty inches in diameter. The gear has a split hub to facilitate easy removal. A combined gear lock and hand wheel is provided.

The Cylinder is of the best grade all heart stock long-leaf yellow pine with hard Maple ribs. The three lifting ribs are extra deep to ensure rapid washing. The trunions are bolted to heavy brass rings. The hinges are of brass bolted through a brass battion with an enclosed brass lock.

The Outer Case is of the finest clear Cypress and is furnished with a brass apron at the door opening. Inspection plates are provided in each end so that trunion bolts may be tightened without removing the upper half of the case.

The Inlet and Outlet Tees are connected by a 1\(\frac{3}{4}\) inch pipe into which steam can be injected. When steam is being used to heat the water this construction gives a rapid circulation and absolutely prevents any steam from coming in contact with the wood of the cylinder or case. The water inlet is 2 inches in diameter. The steam inlet is \(3\frac{1}{4}\) inch. A 3 inch plug type discharge valve is supplied.

This Washer can be arranged for motor drive, in which case it is driven from the motor through short belts. The motor is carried on a substantial cast iron base bolted firmly to the frame of the machine.

At a small additional cost these machines may be equipped with a Beaver 6 inch foot operated discharge valve, Beaver Water Level Indicator, visible anywhere in the wash room, Beaver Soap and Soda filling doors, and Monel Metal Lifting Ribs in the cylinder.

The Canadian Underdriven Solid Curb Extractor

Angle Countershaft

Size
Inside basket shall be 26 inches in diameter.

Basket
Shall be constructed with shell of sheet steel (.109-inch) perforated with sufficient number of holes to permit free discharge of water, heavily galvanized inside and out and riveted to top and bottom of basket.
Top shall be of the same material as shell, reinforced by a steel ring spun in place, and heavily galvanized inside and out.
Bottom shall be of cast iron, of double web construction, truly machined, upper surface covered with sheet copper, heavily tinned.
Shall be reinforced by iron bands shrunk to shell.
Shall be tested for running balance at rated speed.

Curb and Base
Curb shall be an extra-heavy, one-piece casting, equipped with drain openings in bottom and fitted with a detachable cast-iron top ring.
Base shall be an extra-heavy, one-piece casting and shall support the curb, balancing and driving mechanism.
Curb and base shall be securely bolted together, becoming in effect one solid, rigid casting.

Safety Cover
Shall be equipped with hinged safety cover.

Safety Bumper and Spindle
Rubber safety ring shall be fitted on bottom of basket and so arranged that when basket is unevenly loaded the rubber safety ring shall engage with curb bottom, thus preventing basket from striking outer curb when finding its balance. Basket shall be supported on spindle-steel spindle, equipped with driving pulley. Spindle shall be turned and ground to size and taper fit in basket bottom. Shall be secured by a brass lock nut. Lower end of spindle shall have a syphon arrangement, consisting of a hollow chamber, forming an oil reservoir, for circulation of oil around the spindle. (See sectional views on reverse side of sheet.)
The Canadian Underdriven Solid Curb Extractor — Continued

Angle Countershaft

Balancing Device
Base casting shall be equipped with detachable well casting, securely bolted to base, for receiving the balancing device. Within well casting shall be located a phosphor-bronze sleeve bearing for receiving spindle, provided with flange, above and below, which shall be located rubber spring cushions, engaging a flange on well casting and held in place by a spanner nut threaded in well casting. Shall be provided with three hardened, double convex, tool-steel buttons at bottom of bearing, on which spindle shall rotate. Removable flanges shall be fitted on top of bearing in such a manner as to feed oil to spindle and furnish a tight joint, to prevent oil from coming in contact with rubbers.

Brake
Extractor shall be fitted with a friction foot brake attached to base, working on spindle pulley. Shall be equipped with locking device, to prevent sudden shock and hold brake in position until basket stops revolving.

Countershaft and Idlers
Shall have countershaft bolted to curb and base, forming a self-contained part of the machine. Shall consist of a cast-iron bracket supporting the shaft, with its tight and loose pulleys and friction driving pulley, and also guide or idler pulleys. One of the idler pulleys shall be equipped with an adjustable device for taking up slack in belt.

Iron Frames
Cast-iron frames of heavy design, rigidly bolted to the tub heads, shall support the weight of the inside cylinder and outside tub and the driving mechanism shall be bolted to these frames. Frames shall be bolted to the tub heads.

Inlet and Outlet
Located in the center bottom of the tub shall be a cast-iron flange tee, through which the steam and water shall enter and waste water be discharged. Steam shall enter washer through an annular...

steam passage cored in the tee without coming in direct contact with the wood or linen. Connected with the flange tee shall be an outlet pipe, on the end of which a 3-inch quick-opening valve of the hollow taper plug type shall be fitted.

Trunnions and Bearings

Cast-iron trunnions shall be attached to cylinder heads by means of brass-covered bolts and inside of cylinder heads shall be fitted with two brass trunnion rings. The journals of trunnions shall operate in solid bored bearings equipped with easily accessible lubricators. Journal bearings shall be supported by the cast-iron frames.

Gearing

Automatic Reverse Mechanism

Shall consist of three 16-inch diameter pulleys and a worm and cam movement, producing a fixed number of reverse revolutions of the cylinder. Entire shifting mechanism shall be mounted on heavy cast-iron swiveling arm, adjustable to belt at various angles. Rev. T.B.R. Westgate, D.D.,
Field Secretary, M.S.C.O.,
Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I would place before a matter which is of great importance in the equipment of our fire escape system. We have at present the sliding pole fire escape system, and if we had the proper sliding brass poles, it would be almost perfect. We have just the spruce pole now, which is alright until it becomes polished by constant usage. Then it becomes dangerous for the smaller children, on account of their not being able to control their descent.

I would be therefore glad if this matter were placed before the Department, and requisition them for three brass sliding poles, eighteen feet in length each one, and proper mats for landing.

We have our fire drill, and the last time, we were able to empty all dormitories from the time the fire gong sounded until all were on the ground in two seconds over the two minutes. We have over one hundred pupils in, and many are quite small.

Yours faithfully,

(sgd) C.F. Hives.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

Will you kindly look up the correspondence with the Department in connection with the pump. This correspondence took place last end of Feb. or beginning of March. They authorized the sending out of the pump to be repaired. I asked at that time that a replica of the one we had in use should be sent. This was not done, and we had to make a new cement base for the new pump and engine. (I may say that the pump and engine which was sent in was of a newer type.) At that time the Department authorized the sending out of the old one to be repaired so as to have one on hand in repair.

The freighting season had really come to a close before the new one came in, and so I was not able to send the old one out for repair. I am sending it now, and would urgently recommend that a duplicate of the new pump be sent out in place of the one I am now returning. I have explained above that a new base for the pump and engine had to be made. That the pump in use now is far superior to the one we had before.

Will you therefore kindly see if the Department will agree to our having a new pump, (pump only, not engine) Self oiling, Typhoon pump. Capacity, 2500 gal. per. hr. Sold by Fairbanks-Morse Winnipeg. The old pump will be sent to Revillion Freres, Prince Albert, awaiting further instructions from you. I sincerely hope that this matter may be put through successfully both on account of convenience in regard to installing pump, and also in regard to efficiency in our water supply, which is a very important consideration in our institution.

Yours faithfully,

(sgd) C.F. Hives.

Dear Sir:

Re:- PUMP FOR LAC LA RONGE

With further reference to your letter of March 12th last No. 132-2-5 authorizing the purchase of a water pump and engine for our Society's school at Lac la Ronge, I beg to enclose herewith a copy of a letter just received from the Principal of this school pointing out the need of a second pump and recommending that the one to be purchased be exactly the same as the one supplied to this school in March of last year. In your letter referred to above, you recognized the need of this important item of equipment owing to the geographical situation of the school and I beg to recommend that authority be given to Mr. Inspector Bunn of Winnipeg, to purchase the pump suggested by the Principal.

With regard to the disposal of the old pump, particulars as to the condition it was in were set forth in the Principal's letter of February 14th last, a copy of which was forwarded to you on March 9th. As this pump is a different model from the one which was sent in by Mr. Inspector Bunn, the Principal is of the opinion that it should not be returned to the school, but disposed of in some other way, and I beg to recommend that this action be taken. In the meantime the used pump which requires repairs, will be deposited with the Revillion Freres at Prince Albert awaiting further instructions from you with regard to its disposal.
I commend the question of the purchase of the new pump requested to your sympathetic consideration and remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
