Ottawa, January 9, 1928.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, with enclosure, concerning laundry machinery for the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. I am pleased to inform you that on the 21st ultimo an order was placed with the Canadian Laundry Machinery Company for a washer and an extractor with the necessary pulleys, shafting, etc. This equipment is being shipped to Lac la Ronge in care of William Lear, Prince Albert, Sask., and the accounts are being forwarded to the Principal of the School along with complete instructions concerning setting up and operating the machines.

In connection with Principal Hives' letter of the 26th ultimo, I note that he is awaiting instructions with reference to the building of an engine house. If you will refer to my letter of November 30th last, you will find authority for this improvement. In earlier communications it was mentioned that the laundry machinery would be operated by a gas engine. The Principal's letter to you suggests that an additional engine for this purpose is required. Will you let me know if this is the case, so that, if action is taken, it can be done immediately. I may say that there have been several engines supplied for the use of this School during the past few years and the Department wishes the management to use one of these to run the laundry machinery if at all possible.

I regret that the Department cannot favourably consider the supplying of a drying tumbler and a flat iron worker for this school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. T. B. R. Westgate, D.D.,

Dear Secretary:

In reply to your letter of the 13th ult. relative to matter of laundry engine, and engines supplied by the Department during the last few years. The engines we have, supplied by the Department are as follows: 1/2 H.P. gasoline engine supplied with first pumping outfit to supply water for building. This has been used of late years for driving a small washer. The Fairbanks-Morse will know whether or not this size is large enough to drive the new laundry machinery. The next engine is one which came with the second pump and which has recently been discarded for a more up-to-date one. The discarded pump has been sent out, but I have kept the engine, which is a 3 h.p. kerosene. Again you could enquire of the Fairbanks-Morse if this is of sufficient power to drive the new laundry machinery. Then we have a six h.p. kerosene engine, which we use for sawing wood. I do not quite see how we can use this engine for wood sawing and laundry work too. We also have the engine which drives the generator. This is down in the basement in the electric light room.

We have a great number of engines when one counts them up, but unless the 3 h.p. is large enough, I do not see how we can get along without another for the new laundry machinery.

There is one suggestion I would like to make here. These engines are really a great expense on account of the great quantity of expensive fuel used, and it seems to me that each year brings an increase in the quantity used. I am not quite sure, but I rather think that one year's supply of fuel for these engines would almost pay for a steam engine of sufficient size to drive the generator, pump and laundry machinery. Then we would have the central powerhouse. Wood would be our fuel, and I believe the fuel expense would be greatly reduced. Of course it would require a man with steam engineer's certificate. I have that myself, and I believe Hastings would quite easily get his certificate.

If this suggestion does not appeal to you as feasible, and at the same time do not feel it right to get more engines, we could bring the electric light plant out of the basement, establish it in a new powerhouse attached to the laundry, and run the generator and laundry machinery with the one engine. If this were done we should require two hundred dollars for building a proper powerhouse.

We regard to my reason for keeping the 3 h.p. engine and sending the pump back. The new pump is run by a 3 h.p. engine of the same make and style and in case of a breakdown, it is an easy matter to substitute the one for the other.
Yours faithfully,

(sgd) C. F. Hives

Principal.

P.S. I may say that the new laundry machinery has not yet arrived, or I would be able to find out what H.P. would be required to run it. But this can be obtained from the people who supplied the machinery, The Canadian Fairbanks-Morse.
Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada

39-43 The Bible House,

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of Jan. 9th last, 132-2-5, relative to laundry machinery and an engine for operating the same at our Society's School at Lac la Ronge, I beg to submit herewith for your information a copy of a letter just received from Mr. Hives, the Principal of this institution, embodying the information you request with regard to the need of an additional engine. You will observe that the Principal is uncertain as to whether the 3 H.P. engine which he has on hand will be capable of handling the laundry machinery, and as I have not been informed of the size of the washer and extractor which you are supplying, I am unable to reach a decision in this matter. I shall be glad, therefore, if you will take the matter up with the Fairbanks-Morse people, and if you learn that the 3 H.P. engine will be incapable of handling the laundry machinery, have a suitable engine purchased and forwarded at your earliest convenience. It should be consigned to the Rev. C. F. Hives, Principal Anglican Indian School, Lac la Ronge, c/o Revillon Freres, Prince Albert, Sask.

Mr. Hives' suggestion with regard to the construction of a central power house and the installation of a steam engine appears to me to be worthy of careful consideration, but as it will take some time to build the power house and install the engine and machinery, his suggestion should, I think, be left for further consideration at a later date and immediate action taken with regard to the provision of a gasoline engine to operate the laundry machinery.

As letters from all our Schools in the Northern parts of the country express the opinion that there will be an early Spring, it is important that any equipment which is to reach these points should be forwarded at once for transportation.

Dear Sir:

On the 28th. inst. I despatched to you a letter relative to an engine to operate the laundry machinery supplied by your Department to our Society's School at Lac la Ronge. Since despatching that letter I received yesterday a further communication from the Principal of this school, and enclose herewith a copy for your information. As the laundry machinery had just reached the school when the Principal wrote his second letter, he felt it his duty to submit a different recommendation with regard to the method of operating this machinery from that which he had set forth in his letter of February 8th. And as this recommendation seems to me to meet the needs of the situation much more satisfactorily than the one made in the earlier letter, I have just despatched to you the following telegram:

"Please defer action on my letter 28th. inst. relative engine for Lac la Ronge pending receipt of further letter being addressed to you today."

I shall be glad to know, therefore, if you agree to the Principal's recommendation that a new building be erected to accommodate the laundry machinery and the electric light Plant, and that the engine which now drives the generator be utilized to drive the
generator and the laundry machinery as well. You will note that his estimate of the cost of the building is $500.00, but I am unable to guarantee that the total cost including freight on cement, lime, shingles etc. will not exceed this amount. I can assure you, however, that no unnecessary expenditure will be incurred and will be glad to have a reply to this communication by wire, setting forth your decision in the matter and furnishing me with an authorisation to proceed with the erection of the building, should the Principal's recommendation receive your approval.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary M. S. C. C.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Building for laundry machinery at Lac la Ronge.

With reference to my letter of the 1st instant, and your telegram on March 8th, in reply to the same, relative to the provision of a building for the laundry machinery and lighting plant at our Lac la Ronge School, I beg to state that as the cost of this building was estimated by the Principal to be $500.00 and a sum of approximately $2,000 was available for improvements at this School this year, the Principal has been authorized to proceed with the erection of this building at once. Out of the $1,500 remaining from the total sum available, our Commission desire that the provision of the infirmary be given first consideration. Should the erection and equipment of this building consume the whole of the $1,500 the provision of the flooring, tables and benches would have to be deferred until the next year.

Trusting this arrangement may meet with your approval.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Field Secretary, M. S. C. C.

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:-

Re:- Sliding poles as fire escapes for Lac la Ronge School, C. of E.

With reference to your letter of Dec. 24th last, (132-2-5) authorizing the purchase of 3 brass sliding poles as part of the fire escape system at our Society's School at Lac la Ronge, I beg to enclose herewith in duplicate the account which has just been presented in this connection by the Manitoba Bridge and Iron Works, Ltd., of Winnipeg.

I enclose herewith also a copy of the written order which was placed with this firm for the above equipment.

You will note that steel poles were substituted for the brass ones you authorized. This firm informed me that the steel would be much cheaper, and being polished would serve equally well. They also informed me that they had received at that time orders for steel poles for two or three other schools for the same purpose through Mr. Indian Commissioner Graham in Regina. For these reasons I authorized the substitution of steel for brass, and trust the action may meet with your approval.

As the fiscal year is drawing to a close, and there will not be another mail from Prince Albert to Lac la Ronge before the first Tuesday in April, I have certified the enclosed bills myself instead of waiting fully two months, as I would have to do, to have them certified by the Principal, and trust you may be able, on my certification, to pay the same.

This bill does not include the freight from Prince Albert to Lac la Ronge, and another account will be submitted.
to you in this connection at a later date.

I have the honour to be, Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.O.C.

Enc.
Ottawa, March 20, 1928.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, enclosing a voucher in favour of the Manitoba Bridge and Iron Works, Ltd., covering the cost of 3 polished steel fire escape poles and freight on same, for the use of the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. This account is being paid and a cheque has been directed to the above company.

I would point out, however, that the receipt, covering the prepaid freight charges of $3.54 on these poles from Winnipeg to Prince Albert, did not accompany your voucher. As the Auditor General may require this receipt, I have to request that you will obtain same from the above company and forward to the Department as soon as possible.

It is noted that you will forward another account covering the cost of the freight on these sliding poles from Prince Albert to Lac la Ronge.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 31st ultimo, number 132-2-5 informing me that funds were available for the building of an infirmary at the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School, and request a proposal with an estimate of the cost in this connection.

I beg to state that I have this day requested Mr. Hives, the Principal of this institution, to furnish me with plans and specifications of a building which he considers would meet the needs of the Lac la Ronge School and district, and an estimate of the cost of the same including equipment, freight charges, etc. As soon as I have received his reply I will communicate with you again.

Thanking you on behalf of our Society for the provision of this much needed building,

I remain, Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith two accounts from the Hudson's Bay Company, and Revillon Freres respectively. These accounts represent expenses in labour on new laundry building for which the Department kindly granted $500.00. When remitting kindly make cheques in favor of the two companies mentioned.

I may say that the building is 36ft X 20ft. It is single story, and on a good cement foundation. The workmanship is in keeping with the main building, and material is of the best. The inside is not yet completed, but when finished will have plaster walls, and wainscoting six feet up. The ceiling is twelve feet.

Yours faithfully,

(sgd) Chas. F. Hives.
Principal

Regina, Sask., Aug. 25th, 1928.

Dear Sir:

In reference to your instructions to me to pay annuity and report on matters in Isle a la Crosse Agency, I have the honor to report as follows:

I was at Lac la Ronge Residential school for five days. This institution is under the Anglican church administration. The Principal is Rev. Mr. Hives who has had fourteen years of work at this place. The school authorities have one of their best men in charge here. Mr. Hives does not just boss the job; he operates the saw mill and can do all construction work himself; he makes all the lime, draws the plans, etc., and turns his hand to every sort of work. Under a Principal of this sort there is no trouble with the staff; they all seem cheerful and busy.

A laundry has just been built here; it is well constructed. Mr. Hives tells me it cost the Department about $500.00; it would have been considered cheap at $3000.00 in some places, but the staff here supplied most of the material and labour.

The building is heated by hot air furnaces, is lighted with electric light, and has a good quality of water throughout. The fire escapes are in a good location; doors to same unlocked and children given frequent practise in using the escape system.

There is a garden here and the boys are employed in working it in the summer. The girls get the usual training in kitchen, laundry and sewing room, and in addition are taught weaving and basket making.

J. W. Waddy,
Paying Agent.
Regina, Sask., Aug. 25, 1928.

Dear Sir:

In reference to your instructions to me to pay annuity and report on matters in Isle a la Crosse Agency, I have the honor to report as follows:

LAG LA RONGE SCHOOL

The dormitories are short of beds, some 17 boys sleeping double. At least ten beds should be sent as soon as possible to this school.

J. W. Waddy.
Agent.
Regina, Sask., Sept. 18th, 1928.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith a report on the annuity payments made in the Isle a la Crosse Agency by Mr. Indian Agent Waddy of the Pas Agency, who made the Treaty 10 Trip this year.

You will note what the Agent says regarding the boys sleeping double at the Lac la Ronge school. This is not as it should be, and I would recommend that the extra beds asked for should be supplied at once.

W. M. Graham.
Indian Commissioner.
Boarding School, Lac la Ronge.

REQUIREMENTS.

Shingle stain for 12710 sq.ft. 1 gal. covers 120 sq.ft.
110 gal. @ $1.50 per gal

Pupil's dining tables. 1 doz. 5 ft. 10 in. in len
Benches for same 2 doz.

Metalic ceiling for dining room. Dimensions under.

Church seats. 38 seats. 10 ft. 8 in. in length.
Regina, Sask., Aug. 25th, 1928.

Dear Sir:

In reference to your instructions to me to pay annuity and report on matters in Isle a la Crosse Agency, I have the honor to report as follows.

LAC LA RONDE SCHOOL

Seats are short in number, 18 medium size single seats should be supplied.

The tables in the dining room are the temporary ones used when the school was under construction; the Principal asks for twelve strong tables, 5ft. 10in. long, covered with heavy linoleum with two dozen benches for same.

The ceiling of the dining room is V Joint and it is in poor shape. The Principal asks for metalic ceiling for it. A plan is attached.

Mr. Hives also asks if the Department would give him a grant to purchase 38 seats, 10'6" suitably stained to place in the church used at the school.

He also asks for a mower and rake which are necessary and $155.00 grant for shingle stain.

J. W. Waddy,
Agent.
Regina, Sask., Sept. 18th, 1928.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith a report on the annuity payments made in the Isle a la Crosse Agency by Mr. Indian Agent Waddy of the Pas Agency, who made the Treaty 10 Trip this year.

I doubt if we could get made tables up in that district. I am afraid they would cost too much money.

It might be economy to send metallic ceiling up for the purpose of covering the V-joint ceiling in the dining room although V-Joint itself should make a perfectly good ceiling.

You will note Mr. Hives is asking the Department for assistance in procuring furnishings for the church at the school. I do not know that the Department will see its way clear to grant this.

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Sir:

Regina, Sask.
Ottawa, October 5, 1928.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the Department wishes to supply some additional furnishings for the use of the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. You should see Dr. Westgate concerning the best method of and time for shipping heavy freight, and you may make the necessary arrangements. Please purchase 12 - 6 ft. institutional beds, 2½ ft. wide, complete with springs, from the best source of supply. You should also order 18 Preston, ball-bearing, single school desks from the Christie School Supply Company, of Brandon, the nearest representatives of the manufacturers of these desks. There should be six of each of sizes 3, 4 and 5. In due course, properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded to the Department for payment. I may say that the beds are quite urgent and I should be grateful if you would make arrangements for their early shipment.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

J. R. Bunn Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Commercial Building,
St. Boniface St.,
Winnipeg, Man.
Ottawa, October 5, 1928.

Reverend Sir:

The Department has examined Mr. Indian Agent Waddy's report on the Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. I am today authorizing Mr. Inspector Bunn, of Winnipeg, to see Dr. Westgate and to place an order for 18 school desks and for 12 beds. These will be shipped at an early date.

I understand that the dining room ceiling should be repaired. You might get a price on metallic ceiling for this room, provided you could be responsible for applying it if the Department made the purchase. You might let me have an estimate of the cost of the lumber necessary for the construction of dining room tables and benches and indicate in your answering letter if you would be prepared to build these if the Department supplied the materials. Battleship linoleum would be a good top for these tables.

I regret that the Department cannot give favourable consideration to the purchase of chapel benches at the present time. Could not these be made at the school? I have also to inform you that it is not the practice to supply shingle stain.

You might let me know what type of mower and rake would be suitable for the use of your school.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. Chas. F. Hives,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Lac la Ronge, Sask.

Dear Sir:

In a letter just received from the Principal of our Society's School at Lac la Ronge, he states that a stove is very urgently required for the new laundry, and requests that an order be placed immediately for a McClary one camp range, 725 Algoma, Wood burning, and complete with water front or one inch pipe waterheating coils. I have been in communication with the McClary Manufacturing Co., and they inform me that the price of this range F.O.B. Prince Albert would be $64.49 the freight from there to the school would amount to $12.50 bringing the total cost up to $77.99. As this item of equipment is undoubtedly very urgently required now that the cold season has commenced, I shall be obliged if you will furnish me with an authorization to purchase and forward the same.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.
Ottawa, November 6th, 1925.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, relative to the request which you received from the Principal of the Lac La Ronge Indian Residential School to be supplied with a stove for the new laundry, and giving an estimate of the cost and freighting of same.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange for the purchase, to the best advantage, of a McClary one camp range, complete with water front. We note that the price of this range F.O.B. Prince Albert will be $64.49, and that the cost of the freight from that point to the school will be approximately $13.50.

Please forward an account, in duplicate, covering the cost of the stove. This you should certify in the usual manner and forward to the Department for payment. You should also obtain an account, in duplicate, covering the cost of the freight from Prince Albert, and this you should certify and forward for payment.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

The Principal of our Society's School at Lac la Ronge has forwarded to me a copy of your letter, dated October 5, 1928, No. 132-2-5, requesting information with regard to the cost of a metallic ceiling for the dining-room at this School, the cost of lumber necessary for the construction of dining-room tables and benches, the type of mower and rake which would be most suitable, etc.

Immediately after receiving Mr. Hives' letter with a copy of your letter enclosed therein, I consulted Mr. Inspector Bunn, and he advised me to apply to various firms for quotations. The replies I received are enclosed herewith as follows:

1. Re the metallic ceiling.
   Western Steel Products Ltd., Winnipeg, estimated cost F.O.B. Prince Albert, $96.09, to this should be added freight from Prince Albert to the School at 3¢ a lb., or approximately $20.00.

2. Re tables and benches.
   (a) The Cusson Lumber Co., Ltd. St. Boniface, Man.
   If made of oak $271.68, F.O.B. Prince Albert, if made of fir, $215.82. To this would have to be added the cost of battleship linoleum, as the oilcloth mentioned is not serviceable. A further sum of approximately $75.00 would have to be added for freight from Prince Albert to the School.
(b) The Acme Sash & Door Co., St. Boniface, Man.
Estimated cost F.O.B. Winnipeg $223.95, to this must be added $41.00 for freight from Winnipeg to Prince Albert and approximately $75.00 from Prince Albert to the School.

(c) Cushing Bros., Saskatoon, Sask.
Quotations not yet to hand.

3. Re Mower and Rake

(a) Cockshutt Plow Co., Winnipeg, Man.
(As Mr. Hives stated in his letter that the smallest procurable were the kind required, I requested quotations accordingly)

| Size | Quotation |
|------|-----------|
| 3½' mower | $90.24 |
| 4½' "     | 91.16    |
| 9' rake   | 53.95    |

to this must be added a certain sum for freight - (1) to Prince Albert, and (2) from Prince Albert to Lac la Ronge.

(b) Massey-Harris Co., Winnipeg, Man.
No quotation yet received.

With regard to the work of installing the metallic ceiling, the Principal states in his letter that the School Management can undertake this without any cost to your Department.

With regard to the making of the tables and the benches, the Principal expresses his regret that the School Management are not in a position to undertake this work. If they are made by any of the firms who have given the quotations set forth above, and sent to the School, knocked down, the School Management will be able to put them together.

As it is very important that the above equipment should reach the School before the winter freighting season ends, I shall be obliged if you will kindly give the quotations submitted your earliest consideration, and either authorize Mr. Inspector Bunn of Winnipeg or our Commission to place orders for the same.

With the compliments of the Season,

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dictated but not personally signed because of absence from the office
